body_text.text: J. Eberlein, T. Harrison, I. McKittrick, M. Wemmer, L.M. Griffin, B.P. Culver, L.A. Johnson, B.A. Kudlow ArcherDX, Inc., Boulder, CO. Introduction: The adaptive immune system is involved in various disease conditions including cancer, chronic infection, autoimmune disease and transplant rejection. Adaptive immunity is mediated by B and T lymphocytes, which are activated upon antigen binding to antigen receptors expressed on their surface. Therefore, the spectrum of these antigen receptors, or immune repertoire (IR), provides a means to monitor adaptive immune responses to disease, vaccination and therapeutic interventions. Next-generation sequencing (NGS) of antigen receptor genes is a valuable tool in the study of disease states and responses to various interventions. Traditional amplicon-based NGS assays use opposing primers for targeted amplification of rearranged antigen receptor genes. Thus, large primer panels are required to capture the extensive combinatorial diversity exhibited by the IR. Quantification from such assays requires a complex system of synthetic controls to account for differential amplification efficiency across segment combinations. Here, we describe an Anchored Multiplex PCR (AMP)-based NGS assay to analyze the IR, employing a minimal set of gene-specific primers in conjunction with molecular barcodes (MBCs) to reduce amplification bias. Methods: AMP uses MBCs ligated to cDNA ends and gene-specific primers for amplification, enabling immune chain mRNA interrogation from a single side. This eliminates the need for opposing primers that bind within the highly variable V-segment, eliminating clone dropout due to somatic hypermutation. Furthermore, this facilitates CDR3 sequence capture from highly fragmented RNA inputs. We validated the quantitative reproducibility and sensitivity of AMP-based B-and T-cell IR assays using high-quality mRNA isolated from peripheral blood leukocytes and highly fragmented RNA isolated from formalinfixed paraffin-embedded (FFPE) samples. Results: Our data showed high reproducibility between replicates and quantitative clone tracking down to 0.01%. Furthermore, our data indicate that clonal diversity in sequencing data is driven by input quantity, total T-cell number, and, to a lesser degree, mRNA quality. Conclusions: AMP-based NGS with MBC quantification and error-correction is a powerful method to characterize the immune repertoire. This enables sensitive clone tracking and measurement of lymphocyte diversity from fragmented RNA samples. Introduction: Target enrichment of selected exonic regions for deep sequence analysis is a widely used practice for the discovery of novel variants, and identification and phenotypic association of known variants for a wide range of practical applications. Current available strategies for selective enrichment can be characterized as either hybridization-based enrichment, where long synthetic oligonucleotides are used to selectively capture regions of interest, or multiplexed amplicon-based, where pairs of short primer sequences leverage PCR to selectively amplify sequence targets. Although hybridization-based methods have proven to be a tractable approach for large panels scaling to whole exome, the approach presents challenges in a relatively high sample input requirement, longer workflows, and inability to scale to very focused panels. In contrast, multiplexed amplicon approaches have proven valuable for small, highly focused panels, yet suffer from inherent challenges including the inability to scale content, loss of specificity associated with PCR duplication, and difficulties annealing primer pairs to already degraded materials. Method: We have developed a technology that utilizes a novel approach to selectively enrich nucleic acid targets ranging from a single gene to several hundred genes, without sacrificing specificity. Fragmented DNA is rapidly hybridized to biotinylated oligonucleotide baits that define the 3´ end of each target of interest. The bait-target hybrids are bound to streptavidin beads and any 3´ off target sequence is removed enzymatically. The trimmed targets are then converted into Illumina-compatible libraries that include unique molecular identifiers (UMIs) and a sample barcode. A Cancer Hotspot panel has been developed to enable highly specific hybridization-based capture of 190 common cancer targets from 50 genes using this technology. Results: The combination of a short hybridization time with the enzymatic removal of 3´ off-target sequence enabled greater sequencing efficiency relative to conventional hybridization-based enrichment methods. With the Cancer HotSpot panel, 100% of bases were covered to 25% or higher of the mean target coverage (MTC), 98% of bases were covered to 33% or higher of the MTC, and 90% of bases were covered to 50% or higher of the MTC. A high percentage of sequence reads also mapped to targets when challenging sample types such as FFPE and circulating tumor DNA (ctDA) were used, and the panel provided minimized bias across sequence content. Conclusions: This one-day protocol enables the preparation of sequence-ready libraries with high specificity, uniformity, and sensitivity for the discovery and identification of nucleic acid variants, even with challenging sample types. B.J. Dokus, H.B. Steinmetz, G.J. Tsongalis, L.J. Tafe Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center, Lebanon, NH. Introduction: Manual assessment of fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) slides is labor intensive, susceptible to interobserver variability and subjectivity and requires technologist and Pathologist review on a fluorescence microscope. We implemented an automated imaging analysis platform into our FISH workflow to alleviate variables associated with manual slide review. Methods: The BioView Allegro Plus (BioView Inc., Billerica, MA) is an automated imaging and analysis system with an 8 slide motorized stage which can scan multiple FISH probe types in a single batch. We validated this system using the PathVysion HER2 probe in FFPE breast and gastro-intestinal tissues (for which the instrument is FDA approved). This system allows for tissue matching of the FISH tissue slide with the H&E slide for the purposes of tumor localization and review of scored cells. The developed workflow includes the following steps performed by a technologist: 1) Scan H&E slide; 2) low resolution scan of FISH slide; 3) tissue matching of FISH and H&E slides to digitally align; 4) select 20 fields of view (FOV) from the regions of tumor previously marked by a Pathologist; 5) scan FOVs at the 60X resolution; 6) review and select 40 cells using the analysis software for classification and scoring using the Solo workstations; 7) second technologist review, formalize the case and electronically assign the case to the Pathologist for final review and verification. Results: Our HER2 FISH validation study included analysis of 50 samples on the Bioview system that have been previously analyzed manually (20 positive, 20 negative and 10 equivocal for HER2 amplification). A significant amount of time and effort was invested into optimizing the operating procedures and establishing a workable protocol before validation could begin. Although there was a significant learning curve, scanned results were comparable to the manual scoring. Harmonized analysis and improved turnaround times were also achieved. Conclusions: Adoption of the BioView Allegro Plus into our Laboratory, although requiring a significant initial investment of time and resources, ultimately allowed for more standardization and automation in the scoring of FISH slides, time savings for the reviewers and provides more accurate correlation with H&E slides. The pathologist can use the Solo web to review the case on a local or remote computer which can also potentially be linked to the laboratory's LIS. With tissue matching, the pathologist can review exactly which cells were selected and scored by the technologist and view the corresponding region on the H&E slide. Both methods require prior knowledge of the fusion partners, have no or limited multiplex capacity, and lack the ability to detect novel fusions. We evaluated the performance of a next-generation sequencing (NGS)-based assay utilizing Anchored Multiplex PCR technology (Archer FusionPlex, Boulder, CO) for detection of gene fusions in RNA isolated from formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded (FFPE) sarcomas in comparison with FISH and cytogenetic findings. Methods: Total RNA was extracted from 17 cases of microdissected FFPE sarcomas including 1 alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma (ARM), 3 alveolar soft-part sarcoma (ASPS), 5 Ewing sarcoma (EWS), and 8 synovial sarcoma (SS). Sequencing analysis for gene fusions was performed using the Universal RNA Fusion Detection Kit (ArcherDX), the Archer FusionPlex Sarcoma Panel (ArcherDX) and the Ion Torrent personal genomic machine (Life Technologies, Carlsbad, CA). RNA from a EWSR1-FLI1 positive cell line (SK-N-MC) and two negative (RNAs from normal blood and FFPE) controls were included. Data were analyzed using the Archer Analysis Pipeline 4.0. All cases had been tested by FISH (14) and/or conventional cytogenetics (3). Results: Gene fusions with specific breakpoints were detected in 15 tumors: ASPSCR1-TFE3 in 3 cases of ASPS; 3 fusion variants in 5 cases of EWS: EWSR1-FLI (3), EWRS1-ERG (1), and FUS-ERG (1); 2 fusion variants in 7 cases of SS: SS18-SSX1 (3) and SS18-SSX2 (4). No fusion was detected in ARM (1) and 1 case of SS. Fifteen of 17 cases had concordant FISH or cytogenetics findings (88%). Two Ewing sarcomas were FISH-negative using the EWRS1 breakapart probe but were positive for EWRS1-ERG (low level) and FUS-ERG fusion, respectively, by this NGS-based assay. Conclusions: This NGS-based gene fusion detection assay is a reliable platform for simultaneous detection of multiple gene fusions from various sarcomas. The assay works well with RNA isolated from FFPE tissue. It is sensitive and can separate different fusions at a single base level. Using this assay, we were able to identify all the translocations identified by FISH or cytogenetics and found fusions that were missed by FISH. Most importantly, this assay allows discovery of new fusions without prior knowledge of the fusion partners, a unique characteristics that neither FISH nor RT-PCR has.

body_text.text: Next-Generation Sequencing-Based Technologies L. Wang, J. Wang, M. Rao, R. Cimera, R. Aryeequaye, L. Cao, R. Benayed, M. Ladanyi, T. Hollmann, K. Busam, M. Hameed Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, New York, NY. Introduction: Gene/locus-specific fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) probes are typically derived from cloned genomic regions presented in BAC (bacterial artificial chromosome) and PAC (P1-derived artificial chromosome) clones. The limitations of these conventional probes are the availability of specific clones and the large size of their genomic inserts (150 to ~300 kb). The use of array-and nextgeneration sequencing-based technologies is expanding our understanding of structural abnormalities at a previously unappreciated resolution, and many of the abnormalities detected are difficult to visualize using conventional FISH. Thus, there is a need to develop high-resolution (<100Kb) FISH probes. We present here our experience with oligonucleotide-based FISH (oFISH) probes which are derived from synthesized oligonucleotides targeting specific sequences in genome. Methods: Two cases with BRAFstructural aberrations revealed by high-resolution SNP-array analysis were studied by FISH using a custom BRAF break-apart probe set consisting of a 300kb probe targeting 5' BRAF (exons 1 to 7 plus 5' upstream sequence) and a 60kb probe precisely targeting 3' BRAF (exons 8 to 18). Probes were synthesized using Agilent's oligo-based SureFISH technology and labeled with FITC (5') and Cy3 (3') fluorophores. FISH was performed on FFPE tissue sections. For comparison, conventional FISH for BRAF gene rearrangement was performed using BAC-clone probes (Empire Genomics). Results: High resolution SNP-array analysis revealed intragenic copy number alterations in BRAF in both cases, showing gain of 3' portion of BRAF and loss or no copy number change of 5' BRAF with the change point mapped to intron 8. The boundaries of the gain segments were clearly defined by BRAF intron 8 and exon 18, whereas the 3' flanking sequence of BRAF was not involved in the gain in either case. FFPE FISH analysis using our custom oFISH probes successfully detected BRAF gene rearrangement with signals consistent with the pattern predicted from array analysis. In contrast, FISH using conventional probes failed to illustrate the BRAF alteration. Furthermore, a targeted RNA-seq assay (ArcherDX) identified in-frame BRAF fusion transcripts in both cases. Conclusions: oFISH probes can provide precise control over the sequence to be targeted, allowing for accurate analysis of regions as small as tens of kilobases. The resolution of oFISH is comparable to that of array-based technology in copy number analysis, therefore, can be used to develop complementary FISH assays accordingly. oFISH works well in FFPE tissue, and the implementation of oFISH probes in clinical diagnosis can significantly improve the precision and accuracy of FISH analysis in selected cases. Introduction: Success rate, accuracy and turnaround time of laboratory results being generated using increasingly complex technologies are of paramount importance in patient care and safety. Occupations that deal with risky technologies in high complexity environments (e.g. aviation, nuclear) apply proactive measures to avoid disastrous consequences of potential errors. We describe our proactive adoption of this model and development of strategies to achieve a High Reliability Organization (HRO) status in a clinical molecular diagnostics laboratory. Methods: We aligned our ongoing patient safety, quality and process improvement strategies with five HRO traits (see results) and Joint Commission Center for Transforming Healthcare's 3-domain (Leadership, Safety Culture, Robust Process Improvement) maturity model. New initiatives, engagement of staff, and proactive use of tools and monitors were added to achieve the goal of high reliability. Results: HRO trait 1-Sensitivity to operations: An operations command center allowed real-time monitoring of critical operational components (IT, staffing, reagents, instruments). An electronic dashboard allowed monitoring of production line, resources, quality, patient safety and training indicators. Industrial and quality engineering expertise were added to the laboratory operations. HRO trait 2-Reluctance to accept "simple" explanations for problems: Detailed root cause analyses and documentation systems allowed identification and remediation of multi-factorial issues. HRO trait 3-Preoccupation with failure: Systematic evaluation of laboratory processes allowed proactive implementation of preventive measures and detailed "Stop the Line" protocols. HRO trait 4-Deference to expertise: A patient safety team (frontline technologist on rotating membership) performed proactive compliance and patient safety risk assessments. A culture of safety was created through open discussions and active staff engagement. Also, a high level of informatics expertise was embedded throughout the lab. HRO trait 5-Resilience: Highly coordinated team efforts allowed the laboratory to continue offering high quality patient care during significant changes such as the laboratory move to a new location, national clinical trial adoptions, automation, implementations of a new LIS and a new institutional EMR, all within a total span of <1 year. Conclusions: Systematic evaluation of laboratory processes, engagement of staff and proactive implementation of laboratory-wide initiatives facilitate strengthening of operations, creates a culture of patient safety and helps to eliminate the risk of errors thereby providing high quality patient care and moving closer to the goal of becoming a High Reliability Organization. Introduction: Deregulation of the MET receptor tyrosine kinase is associated with aggressive phenotypes in a variety of human cancers, promoting proliferation, invasive growth and angiogenesis. Several types of genetic aberrations can drive MET deregulation, including gene amplification, overexpression, single nucleotide variants (SNVs), exon 14 skipping and fusions. MET is a target of intensive drug development efforts, although the various mutated forms of MET exhibit unique drug sensitivities. Therefore, detection of these mutations has the potential to guide treatments for cancers driven by MET deregulation. Next-generation sequencing (NGS) enables comprehensive detection of all mutation types from whole genomes and transcriptomes. However, low detection sensitivity, high input requirement and high costs render these approaches impractical for routine detection of mutations from low-input clinical sample types. Anchored Multiplex PCR (AMP) is a target enrichment strategy for NGS that, by its scalable and quantitative nature, is well suited to detect all modes of MET deregulation. Methods: AMP-based Archer VariantPlex and FusionPlex library preparation assays detect mutations from DNA and RNA, respectively. We designed AMP probes covering the MET gene to detect copy numbers and SNVs from DNA, and fusions, exon skipping and expression levels from RNA. Results: MET amplifications and resulting overexpression were detected in FFPE samples using the VariantPlex and FusionPlex kits and confirmed by FISH. Exon 14 skipping with concomitant splice site mutations was also detected using the Archer kits and confirmed by RT-PCR in both FFPE and cells. Interestingly, we detected a novel GTF2I:MET gene fusion and a Y1253D activating point mutation in FFPE samples. Conclusions: These results show that AMP-based VariantPlex and FusionPlex Assays enable comprehensive detection of multiple mutation types from low-input clinical sample types, such as FFPE specimens.

body_text.text: Suspected B-Cell Clonality Y. Huang, A. Jacobsen, J. Panganiban, K. Hutt, D. Duong, J. Thornes, J. Miller, T. Stenzel Invivoscribe, San Diego, CA. Introduction: PCR-based methods targeting immunoglobulin heavy chain (IGH) frameworks 1, 2, and 3 (FR1, FR2 and FR3) are the current gold standard for the first line clonality testing in suspected B-cell proliferations. Recently, next-generation sequencing (NGS) based approaches for immune receptor geneshave been suggested to improve sensitivity and identify the specific V-J DNA sequence required to track clones in follow up testing. Here we report the development of a comprehensive IGH NGS assay which allows detection of all three FRs, simultaneously, in a single Illumina MiSeq run. Methods: The MiSeq IGH Assay consists of three master mixes, targeting FR1/J, FR2/J and FR3/J regions. The proprietary V and J consensus primers were designed and adapted to enable the PCR products to be sequenced on the MiSeq platform. Each MiSeq IGH FR master mix uses 24 indices, allowing analysis of 22 patient samples plus positive and negative controls. Multiplexed PCR was followed by amplicon purification using the AMPureXP PCR system. Purified equimolar amounts of amplicons from different samples and FRs were pooled to form a library. The harmonized and quantified library was sequenced using the MiSeq v2 Reagent kit (500 cycles). MiSeq output data was analyzed using proprietary bioinformatics software, which can sort the sequences by both index and FR, generate frequency distributions of V-J rearrangements, and determine the somatic hypermutation (SHM) rate of the IGHVregion based on the sequence of FR1/J amplicons. Results: The ability to detect FR1, FR2 and FR3 regions was verified by testing different known V-J rearrangement B cell line DNA. Cell line DNA, serially diluted into tonsil DNA, demonstrated the limit of detection (LoD) at 5% dilution with 50 ng DNA input. The assay achieved good linearity (R 2 > 0.95), and good reproducibility (<25% CV) was demonstrated over 2 operators, 2 MiSeqs and 2 lots of PCR master mixes. Preliminary testing of genomic DNA from peripheral blood (PB), bone marrow (BM) aspirates and formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded tissue (FFPE) demonstrated that the clonality detection missed by one FR could be detected by another FR, thus increasing overall detection rate. Conclusions: A comprehensive IGH NGS assay has been developed for the Illumina MiSeq platform that identifies clonal IGH V-J rearrangements and DNA sequences. The assay has demonstrated that combining FR1, FR2 and FR3 helps to decrease the false-negative rate due to somatic hypermutation in primer binding sites of the involved VH gene segments. Introduction: Accurate detection of low occurrence somatic mutations is paramount when using next-generation sequencing (NGS) based results to direct personalized management of cancer. Between March 2013 and March 2016, the Center for Personalized Diagnostics sequenced 3010 clinical cases on its amplicon based solid tumor panel (Sv1) which covers mutational hot spots across 47 genes. Our potential to include more genes, cover all exons and report variant allele frequencies (AF) of < 5% using low DNA input were limited due to the assay methodology and duplication errors of PCR and sequencing. To address these limitations, we designed our next solid tumor panel (Sv2) using Agilent Haloplex HS methodology that combines molecular barcoding and deep sequencing. We present our data from 48 samples and show that unique molecular identifiers can be used for accurate detection of variants below 5% AF with low DNA input. Methods: The final version of Sv2 captured 99.81% of the 583kbp target region designed to include all exons of 155 genes. We tested 48 DNA samples isolated from FFPE tissues (n=38), blood (n=6) and assay controls (n=4). DNA input range was 25ng to 100ng and all DNA were <30% degraded. Expected AF range was 0.05% to 100% for single-nucleotide variants (SNV) and insertion-deletions (indels). Data were analyzed using SureCall analysis software (v3.5.1.46) from Agilent Technologies. Variants were called only with unique reads, while at least three such reads were required to deem a variant to be true. Results: We successfully generated libraries at all DNA input ranges we tested. We observed >75% duplicate molecules when samples were >15% degraded and/or when DNA input was < 35ng. More than 80% of all target regions had mean coverage >200x when sample mean coverage was >500x and duplicate molecules were <60%. On-target specificity was consistently >98%. SNVs with expected AF <5% (n=28), had 100% sensitivity and specificity across all DNA inputs and sequencing runs. Below 1% AF, we had 100% concordance and accurately detected SNVs at 0.5% (n=3); 0.1% (n=7) and 0.05% (n=2). SNVs with AF >5% (n=38), had 100% concordance and on average AF's varied by 4.5% between runs. Sensitivity and specificity of indels and whole gene/exon alterations for all AF ranges are currently being determined. Conclusions: Accurate identification of somatic mutations in tumors by NGS is required for enrollment into mutation-specific treatment modalities and clinical trials. We show that our Sv2 can reliably detect lowlevel SNVs by tagging DNA fragments with more than a million unique molecular identifiers before PCR. This panel will greatly benefit patients whose tumors carry low-level actionable mutations and those who require monitoring for minimal residual disease.

body_text.text: TT67. An Automated Cell-free DNA Extraction System for Clinical Diagnostics T. Ivanova, A. Fan, A. Yeo, P. Ariyaratne, G. Michel Vela Research Singapore Pte. Ltd., Singapore. Introduction: Circulating cell-free DNA (cfDNA) has emerged as an important biomarker in cancer diagnostics and non-invasive progression monitoring of various clinical conditions. This has resulted in the development of new in vitro diagnostics (IVD) cfDNA assays. Challenges encountered in these developments related to the efficient extraction of cfDNA from liquid biopsies, often yielding low quantities of highly fragmented DNA. As assays for cfDNA are typically intended to identify genetic variants present at very low allelic frequencies, many of the established detection technologies are driven to the edge of their performance. Methods: We developed a magnetic bead-based cfDNA extraction kit Sentosa SX cfDNA Kit (4x8) and optimized it for use on the Vela Sentosa SX101 platform. Sentosa SX101 is a CE-IVD certified robotic liquid handling system for nucleic acid extraction, PCR set-up and Next-Generation Sequencing (NGS) library preparation. We compared performance of the Sentosa SX cfDNA Kit (4x8) with a column-based cfDNA extraction kit. Integrity of cfDNA extracted by both methods was assessed using ALU repeats qPCR assay. Quality of the extracted cfDNA was tested using an NGSbased Sentosa SQ CRC Panel (4x8). Results: The Sentosa SX cfDNA Kit (4x8) utilizes 4 mL of human plasma as sample input and can process up to eight samples per run. In this pilot study DNA was extracted from plasma samples with 3.0, 1.5 and 0.75 ng spiked-in fragmented HCT116 gDNA (KRASG13D positive) using Sentosa SX cfDNA and column-based cfDNA extraction kits, respectively. Fragment size of HCT116 gDNA was ~170 bp (confirmed by Bioanalyzer). The ALU247/115 ratio for DNA extracted by the Sentosa SX cfDNA kit was 0.19-0.28 and for the columnbased extraction method >0.7 (expected ratio for cfDNA is less than 0.5 and for gDNA is 1.0). Amount and quality of DNA for all samples extracted by both methods was sufficient to prepare NGS libraries using Sentosa SQ CRC Panel (4x8). KRAS G13D mutation was detected in all samples extracted by the Sentosa SX cfDNA kit and no KRAS G13D mutation was detected in any of column-based extracted samples. Conclusions: The Sentosa SX cfDNA Kit (4x8) selectively extracts cfDNA over high molecular weight gDNA. The Sentosa SX cfDNA Kit (4x8) appears as an efficient and reliable solution for cfDNA extraction from human plasma samples. Integration into the Sentosa qPCR-and NGS-based workflows makes the Sentosa SX cfDNA Kit (4x8) a universal in vitro diagnostics tool, which can be used in combination with various IVD assays. Introduction: Plasma cell-free DNA is challenging to analyze due to a high degree of fragmentation and low concentration in circulation. Detection of low level mutations in cfDNA requires highly sensitive molecular detection methods. In this study, we compare the utility of the Bio Rad droplet digital PCR (ddPCR) and MassARRAY System, powered by UltraSEEK chemistry for detecting low level mutations in plasma cfDNA. Methods: cfDNA was extracted from plasma of 25 patients with metastatic solid tumors: 14 adenocarcinomas including 7 colorectal, 3 breast, 2 pancreas, 2 intestinal; 1 oral squamous cell carcinoma, 1 mucoepidermoid carcinoma, 6 melanoma, and 3 astrocytoma/glioblastoma using the QIAamp circulating nucleic acid kit within 2-16 hrs of specimen collection. Mutations in primary (n=14) or metastatic (n=11) tumors were tested using the Ampliseq Cancer Hotspot Panel v2 (Thermo Fisher). 10ng cfDNA was used for each assay. cfDNA genotyping was performed for 11 SNPs in IDH1 (R132H), PIK3CA (H1047R, E542K, E545K), KRAS (G12D, G12V, G13D), BRAF (V600E, V600M), NRAS(Q61R, Q61K) genes using ddPCR (Bio Rad) and 12 gene hotspot Ultraseek MassARRAY 1% MAF, all 37 expected calls were detected using the Accel TP53. Further, Accel TP53 assay detected 1 additional nonsense mutation (TP53. c.372C>A p.C124*) at 1.1% MAF (region not covered by TruSeq 53-gene hotspot amplicons). There was a good correlation of MAFs detected by the two assays (R 2 =0.98). The actual hands-on time was ~4.5 hrs (versus ~ 8 hrs on TruSeq 53-gene hotspot assay). Further optimization of the pipeline for improving the limit of detection is in progress. Conclusions: Accel TP53 is a sensitive, high-throughput "single-gene" NGS-based assay for detection of low-level TP53 mutations, suitable for MRD monitoring and early detection of sub-clonal mutations. Compared with the routinely used NGS-based multi-gene panels targeting hot-spot regions, the advantages of this assay include efficient resource utilization and comprehensive coverage of the entire coding region at reduced cost. The need to process small solid tumor specimens is increasing as early detection strategies become more effective and less invasive biopsy strategies are adopted. Moreover, the rapidly changing landscape of molecular testing argues that current strategies need to minimize sample input and preserve tissue for future testing. Processing small regions of tumor can be challenging as traditional manual macro-dissection and purification methods include multiple steps during which material can be lost. We evaluated an approach that combines automated tissue dissection with NGS library preparation directly from fragments of dissected tissue. Methods: FFPE tissue dissection was performed using the Roche Automated Tissue Dissection platform (Roche Diagnostics) which is currently in development. For DNA analysis, tissue fragments were processed using FFPE Direct Reagent (Thermo Fisher) and Ion AmpliSeq Cancer Hotspot Panel v2 (CHPv2) libraries were prepared and run on an Ion PGM system. For RNA analysis, tissue fragments were processed using the HTG Oncology Biomarker Panel (OBP) on the HTG EdgeSeq (HTG Molecular) and libraries were run on an Illumina MiSeq. Results: Automated tissue dissection was performed on slides of unstained sections from archived FFPE cases of melanoma, colon adenocarcinoma, pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma and pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor. For DNA analysis, we dissected areas of tumor tissue from 50 mm2 to 1 mm2. We show that all CHPv2 libraries yielded excellent sequence data and that there was 100% concordance with previously reported mutations. We compared the performance metrics of libraries prepared from 1 mm2 to larger areas of tissue for the same case and found highly correlated amplicon coverages. For RNA analysis, we dissected areas of tumor tissue from 25 mm2 to 1 mm2. The HTG OPB libraries all passed QC metrics and yielded high quality gene expression data. In particular, samples processed from equivalent areas of tumor on adjacent sections yielded highly correlated data. Conclusions: The precision isolation of FFPE tumor provided by automated tissue dissection combined with extraction free DNA/RNA library preparation can be used to minimize material losses and reduce the amount of tissue input. The approach allows the processing of extremely small samples that are otherwise too small for standard NGS analysis.

Roy 1 1 Baylor College of Medicine, Houston TX; 2 Texas Children's Hospital, Houston, TX; 3 Texas Tech University, Lubbock, TX. Introduction: Internal tandem duplications (ITD) are a rare class of oncogenic genetic aberrations in cancers. The recent discovery of recurrent C-terminal ITDs in the X-linked BCL-6 co-repressor (BCOR) gene in diverse childhood solid tumors, including clear cell sarcoma of the kidney (CCSK), primitive neuroectodermal tumors of the brain, and soft tissue sarcomas, highlights the emergence of a useful marker for these diagnostically-challenging tumors. Herein, we describe the development and clinical implementation of a DNA-based fluorescent fragment analysis test to detect BCOR ITDs from formalin-fixed and paraffin-embedded (FFPE) and frozen tumor samples. Methods: Genomic DNA extracted from frozen and FFPE specimens of ITD-positive CCSK tumors (true positives, n=9), an ITD-negative CCSK and tumor-adjacent normal kidney specimens (true negatives, n=7), Wilms tumors (true negatives, n=23), and congenital mesoblastic nephromas (true negatives, n=9) were used. DNA was amplified with specific (6-FAM-labeled forward and unlabeled reverse) primers designed to amplify a fragment of the last coding exon of the BCOR gene that harbors ITDs. Fluorescent Fragments were detected using the ABI 3130 Capillary Electrophoresis system, sized with ABI GeneScan-500 LIZ ISS and analyzed with GeneMapper Software 5 (Life Technologies). Limit of detection studies were performed using serial dilutions of an ITD-positive case with known variant allelic fraction. Results were compared with Sanger sequencing and next-generation sequencing. Results: Fragment analysis-based ITD detection was successfully achieved with a total DNA input of >10ng (FFPE) and >1ng (frozen specimens), at an analysis threshold of 100 relative fluorescence units. Three different ITDs (90 to 96 bp) in eight of nine true-positive samples were detected by the fragment analysis assay (8/9: 89% clinical sensitivity), with the single discordant result being in a sample with degraded DNA. Clinical specificity of 100% was observed with all (39/39) true negative samples confirmed to be ITD negative. A high degree of concordance (0.97, Cohen's Kappa) was obtained between the two methods. Allelic ratio estimation using peak heights (ITD/wild-type) revealed a lower limit of detection of 5% tumor/normal DNA ratio. Both repeatability and reproducibility studies demonstrated sizing variation <0.15bp for the wild-type (expected size 287bp) and ITD fragments. Conclusions: The newly-developed fragment analysis test is a highly sensitive and specific clinical diagnostic tool that can be used on minimal archival FFPE specimens for the detection of BCOR ITDs in tumor specimens. Prospective application of this assay in a wide variety of BCOR ITDpositive tumor types would enable the evaluation of its clinical utility. Introduction: A majority of molecular diagnostic tests using formalin-fixed paraffinembedded (FFPE) tissue start from DNA extraction, a labor-intensive and timeconsuming step. To accommodate increasing demands of DNA-based testing on FFPE samples, we sought to decrease the labor and time of the deparaffinization step of extraction, and combine Zymo Research (ZR) Pinpoint isolation with Qiagen spin columns to facilitate automation of the DNA purification step on the QIAcube. Methods: FFPE slides were deparaffinized using a xylene alternative on the BiogenX Xmatrx NANO, followed by isolation of tissue from areas containing tumor cells using the ZR Pinpoint Solution and DNA extraction using ZR Pinpoint >40% Extraction Buffer and Proteinase K. The DNA purification was compared using the Zymo-Spin I columns (Zymo method) to Qiagen MinElute columns (hybrid method), which allowed us to use QIAcube. DNA quantity was determined with Qubit dsDNA BR Assay Kit and Agilent 2200 TapeStation. Results: Both methodologies require fewer unstained slides compared to our previously validated extraction and purification method, which involves scraping tumor from unstained FFPE slides, xylene deparaffinization, lysis, and purification on QIAamp Mini spin column. The ZR Pinpoint Solution allows for precise tissue selection and less tissue loss compared to scraping method. DNA yields were equivalent in both Zymo and hybrid methods, determined by Qubit BR assay and TapeStation (350-900 ng total), and are higher than our traditional scraping method. OD 260/OD280 ratio ranged from 1.85 to 2.00. Combining ZR Pinpoint DNA isolation with Qiagen DNA purification has enabled us to decrease hands-on time to 30 min from 60 min, when the QIAcube is incorporated; and the total extraction time to 6 hours from 18 to 20 hours. This method also allows for a decrease in error and recovery of more DNA. Conclusions: Automated deparaffinization of FFPE slides followed by ZR Pinpoint isolation of tumor tissue and Qiagen's spin column technology results in DNA yields similar to those of using ZR Pinpoint Isolation System alone. Pinpoint Solution allows for more precise tissue sampling and less loss of tissue than the traditional scraping method. Using Qiagen spin columns enables automation of DNA purification on the QIAcube, and results in significantly decreased hands-on time. Alternative deparaffinization eliminates xylene, thereby decreasing chemical exposure and disposal. This semiautomated hybrid method will increase efficiency as well as the quality of the workflow in our clinical laboratory.

Introduction: Manual processing of specimens for Next-generation sequencing (NGS) is complex and time consuming. Automation can allow for better standardization and improved workflow. The Ion Torrent Chef requires 8 specimens be pooled on an Ion 318 chip, thus 16 specimens per 2 chip sequencing run. However, our lab volume is not sufficient to run two Ion 318 chips per week. We describe an alternative NGS automated workflow with combined data from two Ion 316 chips resulting in improved wet-bench turnaround time, reduced technician hands-on time, equivalent data and the ability to adequately analyze previously inadequate specimens. Methods: Twenty clinical specimens were previously sequenced using a manual workflow and the 50 gene Ion AmpliSeq Cancer Hotspot Panel, the Ion One Touch 2 and the Ion Torrent Personal Genome Machine (PGM). Eight additional specimens that previously failed or were excluded from clinical testing due to low quality or quantity DNA were also included in the study. Laboratory validation was then performed using the Ion AmpliSeq Kit for Chef DL8 and the Ion AmpliSeq Cancer Hotspot Panel v2 on the Ion Chef. Combined libraries were prepared in duplicate (8 specimens per Ion 316 chip including control) using the Ion PGM Hi-Q Chef Kit and Ion 316 Chip Kit v2 for clonal amplification, chip loading and sequencing. Lee Hallym Uiversity, Anyang, Republic of Korea. Introduction: Molecular detection of nontuberculous mycobacteria (NTM) is increasingly important. The Anyplex MTB/NTM Reat-time Detection (Seegene) is a CE-marketed test for direct detection of both MTBC and NTM. Recently new version (V2.0) of the Anyplex MTB/NTM was developed. The Anyplex MTB/NTM Reat-time Detection (V2.0) is an upgraded version for NTM detection. In this study, the sensitivity and specificity of the Anyplex MTB/NTM Reat-time Detection (V2.0) were evaluated for detecting NTM. Methods: Two hundred nineteen NTM culture positive respiratory specimens and 104 AFB stain and culture negative respiratory specimens were evaluated. Real-time PCR was performed by the Anyplex MTB/NTM Reat-time Detection (V2.0). Results: The sensitivity and specificity of the Anyplex MTB/NTM Reat-time Detection (V2.0) were 75.3% (165/219) and 98.1% (102/104) for NTM detection, respectively. Conclusions: The Anyplex MTB/NTM Reat-time Detection (V2.0) could be useful for detecting NTM in respiratory specimens.

FIGREF52.text: Specifications C. Miller, B. Parikh GenomOncology, Cleveland, OH. Introduction: Analytical performance determination is a critical step in the development of a clinical assay. Organizations such as Palmetto GBA's MolDx program have established analytical performance characteristics that assays must meet. This study investigates the analytical performance of a common 50 gene hotspot panel across multiple institutions using MolDx guidelines. Methods: Anonymized SNV and INDEL variant data, including True Positive, False Positive, and False Negative designations from 5 institutions running the Ion Torrent Cancer Hotspot v2 panel (CHP) were pooled. Variant calls were made using Ion Torrent variant caller with default settings. This dataset was used to determine analytical performance for individual institutions and for different variant classes listed in the MolDx analytical performance specifications. Performance was assessed by calculating the point estimates and 95% confidence intervals for positive percent agreement (PPA) and positive predictive value (PPV). Intermediate precision was assessed by comparing the total number of concordant and discordant variant calls for replicate samples. Variant classes were broken down by variant type and variant allele frequency (VAF) as described in the MolDx specifications. Results: The combined dataset covered 500 samples and 4296 variants, of which 926 were unique.

Sequencing analysis for gene fusions was performed using the Archer FusionPlex Lung Thyroid Panel (ArcherDX, Boulder, CO) which has ALK,ROS1,FGFR3, NTRK1, NTRK3, RET, and PPARG genes, and  the Ion Torrent personal genomic machine (Life Technologies, Carlsbad, CA). RNA from a negative control and positive control (EML4-ALK, CCDC6-RET and SLC34A-ROS1) from the vendor were included. Data were analyzed using the Archer Analysis Pipeline 4.0. All the lung tumors were tested by FISH and four of them were tested by a different NGS-based platform (Archer FusionPlex Solid Tumor kit). The thyroid tumors were previously tested negative for BRAF or RAS mutations. Results: Gene fusions with specific breakpoints were detected in 6 of 9 lung adenocarcinomas: EML4-ALK (3), KLC1-ALK (1), CD74-ROS1 (1), and MET exon 14 skipping(1); the presence of fusions in the latter three cases and one of the EML4-ALK fusion-positive cases was confirmed by an alternative NGS-based platform. One case of PTC was positive for TFG-MET and 1 FC was positive for PAX8-PPARG. The three fusion-negative lung adenocarcinomas were all negative for ALK translocation by FISH analysis. Conclusions: Gene fusions in lung and thyroid carcinomas can be reliably detected by this NGS-based assay. Multiple fusion variants including rare fusion types were detected with information of specific exons involved. This assay can be multiplexed and does not require morphologic expertise under fluorescent microscope. Introduction: Transfusion-transmitted infectious diseases remain an important issue for blood safety, particularly with Hepatitis B Virus (HBV), Hepatitis C Virus (HCV), and Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV). Development of nucleic acid test (NAT) technology reduced the transmission risk of these viruses in transfusion. The Cobas TaqScreen MPX Test (Roche Molecular Systems, Inc., Branchburg, New Jersey) is a newly developed qualitative test that enables the simultaneous detection HBV, HCV, and HIV. We performed an evaluation of clinical sensitivity and specificity of Cobas TaqScreen MPX Test comparing with current COBAS AmpliPrep/COBAS TaqMan assays (Roche Molecular Systems) in clinical specimens derived from Korean. Methods: To evaluate the sensitivity of Cobas MPX Test, positive samples from COBAS AmpliPrep/COBAS TaqMan test were collected. Total collected positive samples were 117, 111 and 105 for HBV, HCV and HIV-1, respectively. To evaluate the specificity of Cobas MPX Test, total 510 negative samples were selected. These negatives were all negative from COBAS AmpliPrep/COBAS TaqMan HBV, HCV and HIV-1 test. Any samples that showed discrepancy between Cobas MPX Test and COBAS AmpliPrep/COBAS TaqMan were confirmed by direct sequencing using 3500xL Genetic Analyzer. Sensitivity, specificity, concordance rate and 95% confidence intervals were calculated. Results: All positive samples showed positive results by Cobas MPX Test. Sensitivity of Cobas MPX Test was 100% (333/333, 95% CI 98.90-100.00). Overall specificity of Cobas MPX Test was 99.59% (508/510, 95% CI 98.54-99.95). In HCV and HIV-1 evaluation, all negative samples were also shown to be negative by Cobas MPX Test (510/510). But, in HBV evaluation, nineteen negative samples showed positive results. These discrepant samples were confirmed by nested PCR and direct sequencing, which demonstrated the 17 samples as positive among 19 samples. Assuming remaining 2 positive samples were false positive, the specificity was 99.59% (508/510, 95% CI 98.54-99.95). The overall concordance rate and kappa coefficient (K) were 97.75% (824/843, 95% CI 96.50-100.00) and 0.95 (95% CI, 0.93-0.97, p<0.0001). HCV and HIV-1 test showed concordance rate of 100% (843/843, 95% CI 99.56-100.00). HBV test showed a concordance rate of 97.75% (824/843, 95% CI 96.50-100.00), kappa coefficient of 0.90 (95% CI, 0.86-0.95, p<0.0001). Furthermore, because of the advantages with fully automated sample preparation and multiplex detection method, the Cobas MPX Test can improve the efficiency and reduce costs and the turn-around time of the NAT for transfusion in clinical laboratories.

Introduction: Zika virus has caused concern by many government health officials in fear that the virus might spread into local communities within non-infected regions of countries. As a potential public health threat, government health officials have been implementing processes to monitor travelers from endemic regions with known outbreaks of Zika viral infections to prevent or minimize any spread of the disease within non-infected regions of the country of interest. As an outcome of the potential public health issues caused by Zika viral infections, a study was performed at the request of the Beijing Entry-Exit Inspection and Quarantine Bureau in China to monitor travelers returning from Latin American countries known to have outbreaks of Zika viral infections. Methods: A real-time PCR assay for Zika virus detection was obtained from Coyote Bioscience (Beijing, China) and delivered to the department of Entry-Exit Inspection and Quarantine Bureau at the airports of Zhejiang, Liaoning, Shanghai, Shenzhen and Beijing. Also, a real-time PCR instrument (i.e., Mini 8) from Coyote Bioscience (Beijing) was also used at the airports to run the Zika virus POC testing. As travelers were identified for testing, a saliva sample was collected. The saliva sample (10on the Mini 8 thermocycler without any sample preparation or nucleic acid purification. Positive and negative controls were also provided and run. A total of 500 samples were run. The reference assay in the study was obtained from the China CDC in Beijing. Results: A total of 500 tests were performed. Of the 500 saliva samples run, the Zika Virus Assay (Coyote Bioscience, Beijing) detected 3 positive travelers as infected with the Zika Virus. Subsequent testing of the travelers was confirmed from the CDC in Beijing, China as being infected by the Zika virus. The travelers tested positive were 2 individual (male and female) from Venezuela and 1 individual (male) from Bolivia. Conclusions: Members of the Beijing Entry-Exit Inspection and Quarantine Bureau conducted Zika testing at the airports of China as a public health study. Results from the testing identified 3 infected individuals out of 500 tested. The infected individuals were returning to China from travel in Latin American countries with known regions of Zika viral infections. The clinical study of testing returning travelers for Zika viral infection at a point of entry in airports proved to be useful as a public health tool in identifying infected individuals.ID59. TABREF27.text: Norovirus Direct and Cepheid's Xpert Norovirus P.Lee, R. Huang, K. Ramos, A. Tran Ha, M. Tabb  DiaSorin Molecular LLC, Cypress, CA.   Introduction: Norovirus, a highly contagious virus, is responsible for 60% to 80% of all human gastroenteritis outbreaks worldwide in diverse settings such as healthcare facilities, restaurants, schools, and cruise ships. Rapid and accurate detection of norovirus infections is important in preventing the spread of the virus in healthcare and non-healthcare settings. Simplexa Norovirus Direct is currently in development as a CLIA moderate complexity sample-to-answer assay performed on the Integrated Cycler System. The assay detects and differentiates norovirus genogroup I (GI) and II (GII) from raw human stool (formed and unformed). The objective of this study was to compare Simplexa Norovirus Direct to Cepheid's Xpert Norovirus using a panel of Norovirus positive and negative specimens and to assess their ability to detect a panel of genotypes. Methods: For the Simplexa Norovirus Direct assay, raw human formed and unformed stool specimens were suspended in sample buffer and loaded directly onto the Direct Amplification Disc (DAD). Results were generated in approximately in 90 minutes. For the Xpert Norovirus assay, Cepheid's package insert was used. The assay's intended use is only for raw or unpreserved unformed stool specimens. The panel in the study was comprised of both formed and unformed stool specimens and both specimen types were subjected to the same package insert procedure. A panel of 15 genotypes, characterized by sequencing, was also tested on both assays. Results: Using the 151 clinical specimens, agreement between Simplexa Norovirus Direct and Xpert Norovirus assays were as follows: positive GI agreement, 97.7% (42/43); positive GII agreement, 100% (48/48); negative GI agreement, 97.2% (105/108); and negative GII agreement, 95.1% (98/103). There were 2/151 samples that were invalid on the initial Xpert run, but were valid in repeat testing. No samples were invalid in the Simplexa assay. Both assays were able to detect genogroup I types GI.2, GI.3, GI.6, GI.7, and GI.8 and genogroup II types GII.2, GII.3, GII.4 (Den Haag 2006b and Sydney 2012), GII.6, GII.7, GII.10, GII.13, GII.14, GII.17 and GII.20. Conclusions: The Simplexa Norovirus Direct assay was able to detect and differentiate norovirus GI and GII in 151 raw human stool specimens; performance was comparable to the Cepheid's Xpert Norovirus assay. Unlike the intended use of the Xpert Norovirus assay, the Simplexa Norovirus Direct has been developed for both formed and unformed human stool specimens. It also provides a compact system for a rapid detection of Norovirus using the Integrated Cycler System. The Simplexa Norovirus Direct assay is in development, is not commercially available, and is not FDA cleared.ID62. Barry CPA Lab / Norton Healthcare, Louisville, KY. Introduction: Copan ESwab (ES) is a FDA approved device for the collection and transportation of clinical microbiology specimens. Methods: A total of 27 specimens were evaluated; 13 vaginosis panel (VP) consisting of fungi (Candida albicans [CA], Candida glabrata [CG]), bacteria (Gardnerella vaginalis [GV]) and protozoa (Trichomonas vaginalis [TV]) and 14Herpes Simplex virus 1 and 2 (HSV1&2). All specimens for VP were vaginal swabs and HSV1&2 comprised of 6 vaginal, 3 penile, 2 lesions (unspecified), 1 lip, 1 vulvar, and 1 other (unspecified). In addition each pathogen was spiked in to ES, for stability testing, using an aliquot from commercial controls with known concentrations and tested at days 0, 3, 4 and11 with vials stored at room temperature. Testing was performed on the ARIES system (Luminex corporation, Austin Texas) using a Multi-Code real-time PCR technology. Results were reviewed using cycle threshold (Ct) and melt curve (TM) analysis on ARIES for the HSV IVD tests per manufacturer protocol and in the SYNCT software using the UDP (User Defined Protocol) for VP. Results: TM for every replicate in the VP fell within the expected ranges that positively identify that respective organism; CA-avg CT-35.37, range-33.2-36.5, CGno positive patients, GV-avg, TV-avg CT-22.7, range-N/A (only one positive patient). HSV1&2-avg. Stability studies showed consistent results on day 0 through day 11 for all targets with CA, CG and GV actually showing a reduction of CT on day 11 compared to day 0; CAday 0 /day 11 CTs -34.25 / 31.05, CG -day 0 / day 11 CTs -25 / 22.1, TV -day 0 / day 11 CTs -28.55 / 29.6, GV -day 0 / day 11 CTs -27.9 / 26.45, HSV1 day 0 / day 11 CTs -29.35 / 29.45, HSV2 day 0 / day 11 CTs -29.35 / 28.9. Conclusions: ES 480C is a robust and reliable medium for the collection, transportation and storage of a variety of microbiologic specimens and can be used for a broad range of organisms.

Miller1  1 University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, Chapel Hill, NC; 2 University of North  Carolina Health Care, Chapel Hill, NC.   Introduction: Clostridium difficile is a Gram-positive, spore-forming, toxin-producing bacterium that colonizes the human gastrointestinal (GI) tract causing a spectrum of disease from mild diarrhea to toxic megacolon. Timely diagnosis correlates with reduced transmission, morbidity, and mortality. However, there is no current consensus on diagnostic testing algorithms. At our institution we utilize enzyme immunoassays (EIA, Alere) to examine liquid stool samples for the presence of toxins A/B (Tox) and glutamate dehydrogenase (GDH). Tox + /GDH + and Tox -/GDHresults are reported as positive and negative, respectively. Single positive results are further characterized by GeneXpert PCR and reported based on the PCR result. In 2013, we implemented the Luminex xTAG GI Pathogen Panel (GPP). The GPP utilizes multiplex PCR to simultaneously identify 14 GI pathogens including C. difficile via detection of genes encoding toxins A/B. In this study, we performed a comparative analysis between the two diagnostic approaches and evaluated if molecular quantification of toxin genes correlated with active infection versus colonization and disease severity. Methods: We performed a one-year retrospective data review to identify liquid stool samples from patients at our institution analyzed by both EIA and the GPP. A subset of patients with GPP + but Tox -GDHresults were identified and a comprehensive chart review was performed to distinguish active infection from colonization, determine disease severity, and correlate these findings with GPP median fluorescence intensity (MFI) measurements. Results: From 2013-2014, we performed 1675 GPP analyses and 1106 had additional EIA/NAAT testing with a concordance rate of 94.2%. When compared to EIA/NAAT, the GPP exhibited a sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value (PPV), and negative predictive value of 93.2%, 94.4%, 69.3%, and 99.0%, respectively. Consistent with a poor PPV, 30% (54/179) of GPP + samples were Tox -/GDH -. Chart reviews identified a subset of these patients with high clinical suspicion of active infection. Conclusions: High analytical sensitivity is the Achilles heel of molecular approaches to the diagnosis of infections caused by organisms, such as C. difficile, whose presence alone is not indicative of disease. Whereas there was high concordance between methods, GPP identified more positive patients, some of whom were true clinical positives.ID64. A Novel Laboratory-Developed Test for Trichomonas vaginalis Detection in Male Urine Specimens on the Cobas 4800 SystemN.R. Jackson 1 , S. Favaloro 2 , C.F. Kletecka 1,2 , C.L. McGowin1  1  Louisiana State University Health Sciences Center, New Orleans, LA; 2 University Medical Center, New Orleans, LA. Introduction: Trichomonas vaginalis is the most common curable sexually transmitted infection (STI) worldwide. In women, trichomoniasis is characterized primarily by signs and symptoms of vaginitis, but the disease spectrum and prevalence are not well understood in men. Although predominately asymptomatic, T. vaginalis infections in men have been associated significantly with non-gonococcal urethritis (NGU). Currently, no FDA-cleared nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) is available for the diagnosis of T. vaginalis infections in men. In this study, we sought to optimize our laboratory-developed test (LDT) on the Cobas 4800 system to determine the prevalence of T. vaginalis in Louisiana men. Methods: Our quantitative, TaqMan-based T. vaginalis LDT was adapted and optimized for use with the User Defined Workflow software (UDF) for the Cobas 4800 system. This study utilized DNA eluates remaining after cobas CT/NG testing of first void urine (FVU) specimens from Louisiana men (n=88). Using the optimized LDT, we assessed the prevalence and microbial burden of T. vaginalis infections in FVU specimens. Results: Using DNA eluates obtained after cobas CT/NG testing on the 4800 system, the T. vaginalis LDT was characterized by excellent intra-and interassay reproducibility (coefficient of variation values all <2.0). The prevalence of T. vaginalis infection was 3.41% (3/88). The mean organism burden was 1.2x10 4 organisms per mL of urine. Once-weekly freeze/thaw cycles for up to 4 weeks had no significant impact on template quantitation indicating the extended stability of frozen cobas 4800 eluates. Conclusions: These results highlight the utility of the UDF system for qualitative and quantitative T. vaginalis detection from male FVU specimens. In addition, residual cobas 4800 eluates appear to be stable upon frozen storage and amenable for downstream PCR applications. LDTs are a cost-effective approach for both clinical diagnostics and research. LDT diagnosis of T. vaginalis is particularly appealing since it can be performed using remnant specimens collected for other STI testing.ID65. Detection of Ebola and Malaria Using General Purpose Reagent (GPR) 1-Step Multiplex Reagents C.Dhanatya, D.P. Blanchard, J. Wang, J.F. Stevens  Thermo Fisher Scientific, South San Francisco, CA.  Introduction: Last year, the devastating Ebola virus outbreak in West Africa occurred in regions with high occurrence of Malaria. Due to the early symptoms of Ebola and Malaria being similar (fever, headache, chills, and vomiting), a method to distinguish whether a febrile patient has been infected with Ebola, Malaria, or both is jmd.amjpathol.org ■ The Journal of Molecular Diagnostics crucial in early diagnosis and treatment. As a result, there is a constant need for test methods that require minimal hands on workflow and fast time to answer while achieving maximum sensitivity and high data quality. 1-step qPCR multiplex is an ideal solution because of its compatibility with RNA, which reduces the number of workflow steps. In addition, multiplex maximizes use of limited samples while enabling the addition of more controls. Methods: Ebola Virus Glycoprotein (ABY), Ebola Virus Nuclear protein (FAM), Malaria Plasmodium falciparum (VIC), and MS2 bacteriophage -positive control (JUN) assays were run in 1-step qPCR multiplex reactions using Thermo Fisher's GPR TaqPath 1-Step Multiplex Master Mix and.The TaqPath 1Step Multiplex Master Mix contains Mustang Purple as a passive reference whereas contains no passive reference. 20ul reactions were amplified using a Thermo Fisher QuantStudio 7 Flex 384-well real-time instrument. MS2 RNA was ordered from ATCC. Ebola and Malaria RNAs were generated from Geneart DNAstrings by transcription using Ambion Megascript T7 transcription kit and then column purified with Ambion Megaclear RNA purification kit. The resulting Ebola and Malaria RNA were quantified with nanodrop and Qubit. Samples were serially diluted and run in both multiplex and singleplex reactions. Results: Side by side comparison of the Ebola and Malaria viral targets show the same LOD (limit of detection) when run in multiplex and singleplex. For the Ebola assays, LOD of 10 RNA copies per reaction was achieved. Infected Ebola patients register 104.4 to 105.2 genomes/mL of blood, which means as little as 100 ul of patient blood would be sufficient to generate quantitative results using this 1-step multiplex test method. For the Malaria assay, LOD of 100 RNA copies per reaction was achieved. With typical Malaria parasite loads ranging between 44-409 genomes/ul of blood, as little as 10ul of patient blood would be needed to generate results using this 1-step multiplex method. No significant change in Ct was observed between multiplex and singleplex data assay conditions. Conclusions: Our testing supports that 1-step qPCR multiplexing is an ideal solution for early diagnosis and treatment of viruses such as Ebola and Malaria that co-circulate in the same regions.ID66. TABREF30.text: Detection of Adenovirus, Parainfluenza Virus, and hMPV Using Simplexa Respiratory Virus Direct Assay H. Gregson, J. Granados, R. Martin, M. Tabb DiaSorin Molecular LLC, Cypress, CA.Introduction: Rapid and accurate detection of respiratory pathogens is important for the diagnosis of respiratory infections. Direct fluorescent antibody (DFA) testing and culture typically take up to 48 hours. One approach to expediting results is the use of molecular respiratory assays that detect a large panel of pathogens; however, a clinician may not want to test all targets on the panel. In an effort to provide a complete and flexible alternative solution, we are developing a real-time PCR respiratory viral panel that detects adenovirus, parainfluenzavirus (hPIV), and human metapneumovirus (hMPV) directly from nasopharyngeal (NP) swabs. The panel can be used alone, in combination with or as a reflex to two other respiratory panels; results are available in approximately 80 minutes using the Integrated Cycler. Methods: Simplexa Respiratory Virus Direct assay detects 3 virus targets (adenovirus, human parainfluenza virus 1, 2, 3, and 4, and hMPV). Nasopharyngeal (NP) swab specimens in viral transport media were loaded directly onto a Direct Amplification Disc without up-front nucleic acid extraction or other specimen preparation; real-time PCR and detection followed specimen loading. Analytical reactivity of the Simplexa Respiratory Virus Direct assay was assessed using virus spiked into negative matrix (UTM). Patient samples were tested using the Simplexa Direct assay. Results were compared to historical data. Results: Analytical reactivity experiments demonstrated that the assay detects: 14 adenovirus strains tested covering all known serotypes (A through G) at concentrations between 10 and 100 TCID50/mL; 9 hMPV strains at concentrations between 10 and 100 TCID50/mL; and parainfluenza virus 1, 2, 3, and 4 between 10 and 100 TCID50/mL. Thirty-one of 32 samples tested with the Simplexa Direct assay returned results in agreement with the historical results.Conclusions: The newly developed Simplexa Respiratory Virus Direct assay detects adenovirus, parainfluenza virus 1 through 4, and hMPV. This assay can be performed simultaneously with Simplexa Flu A/B & RSV Direct and Simplexa Bordetella Direct to detect a panel of 9 respiratory pathogens (Flu A, Flu B, RSV, adenovirus, parainfluenza virus (1, 2, 3 & 4), hMPV, B. pertussis, B. parapertussis and B. holmesii) from one patient sample. Simplexa Bordetella Direct and Simplexa Respiratory Direct assays are in development; they are not currently available for sale and are not FDA cleared. ID69. Characterization of GenMark ePlex Respiratory Pathogen Panel and Comparison to BioFire FilmArray RP Panel A.R. Schroeder, D. Osato, K. Henthorn, J. Moberly, K. Wong, N. Mohamed, C. Hoeft, R. Vansickle, A. Safavi, G. Borillo, S. Kulkarni, P. Le, L. Freeman-Cook GenMark Diagnostics, Carlsbad, CA. Introduction:The clinical presentation of respiratory viruses can vary, but significant overlap exists in the clinical manifestation, and more than one causative agent may be involved, making diagnosis challenging. Appropriate treatment of respiratory illness depends on accurate and timely diagnosis.The ePlex Respiratory Pathogen (RP) Panel is designed to detect 18 viruses and 4 bacteria in approximately 90 minutes. The single-use cartridge contains reagents required to enable sampletoanswer performance, including sample extraction, PCR amplification, and detection via GenMark's proprietary eSensor technology. The objective of this study was to characterize performance of the ePlex RP Panel by 1: determining the test's limit of detection using contrived samples and 2: evaluating performance of the ePlex RP Panel using clinical nasopharyngeal swab (NPS) specimens previously tested by the FilmArray RP panel. The ePlex RP Panel is currently under development. Methods: To evaluate the analytical sensitivity and inclusivity of the ePlex RP Panel, samples were prepared by diluting titered cultures into viral transport media. For each analyte, serial dilutions were tested to determine the lowest detectable sample concentration. The ePlex RP Panel performance was also evaluated by testing 175 residual frozen clinical NPS samples, previously identified to be positive by the FilmArray RP Panel for a single infection (101 samples), positive for co-infection (22 samples), or pathogen negative (52 samples). Results: Analytical sensitivity was determined for all targets on the ePlex RP Panel. The majority of targets demonstrated equivalent analytical sensitivity relative to both XT-8 RVP and the FilmArray RP Panel, and no cross-reactivity was observed. In clinical samples previously characterized by the FilmArray RP Panel, the ePlex RP Panel detected the expected targets in 97.7% of samples after discordant resolution. Four targets were detected by the FilmArray RP that were not detected by the ePlex RP Panel, and 17 additional targets were detected by the ePlex RP Panel that were not detected by the FilmArray RP Panel. Conclusions: The ePlex RP Panel demonstrated high analytical sensitivity in detecting a broad range of respiratory pathogens. Furthermore, the performance of the ePlex RP Panel testing clinical samples previously characterized by the FilmArray RP Panel demonstrates the capability of eSensor technology and the high quality of the ePlex system. The ePlex RP Panel is designed to provide valuable information to help make impactful decisions through rapid and comprehensive identification of respiratory pathogens.ID70. Baden1  1 Janssen Diagnostics, a Johnson and Johnson Company, Raritan, NJ; 2  Biocartis NV, Mechelen, Belgium. Introduction: Rapid, accurate quantitation of HIV-1 viral load (HIV-1 VL) is critical for successful clinical management of HIV-1 infected patients. The HIV-1 VL prototype assay can potentially be used to assess patient prognosis by measuring baseline HIV-1 levels or to monitor the effects of antiretroviral therapy by measuring changes in plasma HIV-1 RNA levels during the course of antiretroviral treatment. The Idylla molecular diagnostics platform fully automates and integrates sample purification, nucleic acid amplification, and detection of target sequence in samples using realtime PCR within a disposable cartridge. The single-use cartridge is preloaded with all reagents and is capable of processing samples with no user manipulation, minimizing the possibility of errors in setup and decreasing the likelihood of contamination. The aim of this work was to demonstrate the performance of the HIV-1 VL prototype assay on the Idylla platform. Methods: Performance of the prototype HIV-1 VL assay was assessed against HIV-1 positive plasma panels consisting of serial dilutions of high copy number viral isolates of subtypes B and C of Group M and Group O for preliminary assessment of linearity and limit of detection. Preliminary inclusivity testing was also performed on the commercially available HIV-1 Genotype Performance panel consisting of 9 representative subtypes of group M and viral isolates of group O. Finally, a limited study was performed on HIV-1 positive patient plasma samples to assess performance of the HIV VL assay against an FDA approved molecular test. Results: The prototype Idylla assay demonstrated high analytical reactivity by detecting all HIV-1 group M subtypes A-D, F-H, AE, AG, and group O at the level of 5 x 10^4 copies per mL. Mean log10 results for all tested subtypes and group O were within +/-0.5 log10 of the input concentrations assigned by COBAS AmpliPrep/COBAS TaqMan HIV-1 Test. The initial limit of detection for the HIV-1 group M subtypes B and C and group O panels in EDTA plasma was less than 40 copies/mL. The preliminary linearity range of the Idylla HIV VL assay was verified within 6 logs of the assay dynamic range with R 2 value greater than 0.98 for both group M and group O viral isolates. Conclusions: The fully automated prototype HIV-1 VL Idylla assay design requires less than 2 minutes of hands-on time for sample handling and provides results in less than 2 hours without need for skilled personnel. It is a rapid, sensitive test capable of determining the presence of viral RNA for an array of HIV-1 group M and group O subtypes. The all-in-one cartridge assay format makes it an attractive option in the future for patient management in either global public health or primary care settings.ID72. Monga 1 , J. Mosner 1 , A. Patel 1 , C. Wagner 1 1 Siemens Healthcare, Berkeley, CA; 2 Siemens Molecular Diagnostics, Berkeley, CA. Introduction: Zika virus (ZIKV) is a Flavivirus first identified in 1947 in Uganda. The WHO has declared that the ongoing outbreak of ZIKV in the Americas constitutes a PHEIC (WHO, Zika Virus Fact Sheets 2016). We present analytical studies and a method comparison with clinical samples of a qualitative diagnostic real-time PCR assay, the VERSANT Zika RNA 1.0 Assay (kPCR) (VERSANT Zika RNA 1.0 Assay (kPCR) under feasibility evaluation. Not for sale and its future availability cannot be guaranteed). Methods: The VERSANT Zika RNA 1.0 Assay (kPCR) qualitatively detects ZIKV RNA. ZIKV RNA from plasma or serum is extracted using the VERSANT kPCR Sample Prep with VERSANT Sample Prep 1.0 Reagents Kit and amplified on the Thermo Fisher QuantStudio 5, Bio-Rad CFX96, or Applied Biosystems 7500 cyclers. Two amplification reactions, targeted to portions of the NS2 and NS5 regions of ZIKV, comprise the assay. Inclusivity of the assay was evaluated in silico comparing primer/probe sequences against 35 unique Zika sequences from 14 countries. Introduction: Physicians rely on clinical symptoms and/or rapid point-of-care (POC) antigen detection tests for initial management of patients with influenza like illness. The POC antigen methods are fast but have lower sensitivities compared to central lab based diagnostic tests. Central laboratory based testing with moderately complex polymerase chain reaction (PCR) influenza tests is both sensitive and specific. The limitation with central laboratory based testing is the delay in the result due to transport of the samples to the lab, and the time required to perform the test.Two CLIA Waived molecular POC influenza A/B assays are now available that provide results in 15 minutes to 20 minutes: cobas Liat Influenza A/B test a PCR assay and Alere i Influenza A & B test an isothermal nucleic acid amplification assay. This is the first comparison of both these assays to moderately complex PCR. Methods: We evaluated the performance of the Cobas Liat Influenza A/B test a PCR assay and Alere i Influenza A & B test for the detection of influenza A or B during the winter flu season of 2016 at Tricore Reference Laboratories (TRL) in New Mexico. The GenMark Respiratory Viral Panel (RVP), the current standard of practice at TRL, was used as the reference method. Eighty seven de-identified residual prospectively collected nasopharyngeal samples (29 positive Flu A, 18 Flu B, 40 negative) collected in VTM M5 -tested on the Cobas Liat and Alere i assays at TRL. Results of the reference assay GenMark RVP were blinded to the operators conducting the POC tests who were not training lab technologists. Results: The overall performance of Cobas Liat Influenza A/B assay demonstrated a sensitivity of 97.9% and specificity of 97.5% in comparison to GenMark RVP with individual sensitivities of 100% and 94.4% for influenza A and B and specificities of 98.3% and 100% respectively. The overall performance of the Alere i Influenza A/B assay demonstrated a sensitivity of 63.8% and specificity 97.5% in comparison to GenMark RVP with individual sensitivities of 55.2% and 72.2% for influenza A and B and specificities of 98.3% and 97.1% respectively. In this evaluation the performance difference in the sensitivities of these two assays was statistically significant. Conclusions: The results demonstrate that these molecular POC tests have different performance profiles. The Alere i's isothermal nucleic acid amplification test's low sensitivity indicates it may not be a suitable replacement for moderately complex PCR testing. The Cobas Liat PCR test demonstrated sensitivity equivalent to lab based PCR, indicating it can be used at the point-of-care to replace rapid antigen tests and/or confirmatory testing. ID74. Introduction: BRAF is an important member of the mitogen activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway that influences cell proliferation. BRAF mutations are found in many cancer types including melanoma, colorectal cancer, hairy cell leukemia, thyroid cancer, lung cancer and ovarian cancers. This BRAF gene mutation analysis assays will differentiate all V600 mutations of the BRAF gene, allowing the determination of drug response, aiding the diagnosis and providing the prognosis information. In this study, we have evaluated the clinical and analytical performance features of this assay. Methods: Genomic DNA was isolated from tumor specimens (FFPE block/slides, bone marrow, blood, fine needle aspirate). Exon 15 of the BRAF gene was subjected to SNaPShot multiplex PCR and primer extension for V600 mutation detection. DNA from a variety of cancer specimens were used to evaluate accuracy, repeatability, reproducibility and analytical sensitivity of the assay.Results: Of the specimens tested during validation, 27 specimens with known mutations in BRAF had SNaPshot analysis results that were 100% concordant. Repeatability (intra-assay precision) and reproducibility (Inter-assay precision) were 100% concordant. This assay can detect 5% of mutant DNA in a background of wildtype genomic DNA when the input DNA is 25ng or more. The BRAF SNaPshot assay has been offered as a clinical test based on the successful performance features. Of the 1368 colorectal specimens tested so far, 21.20% had a BRAF V600E mutation detected; 2.60% BRAF mutations (V600R, V600D) were found in 77 lung cancer specimens; 49.09% (V600E, V600G, V600M) were found in 55 thyroid cancer; 50% (V600E, V600D, V600A) in 75 leukemia/lymphoma with 63,64% in 44 hairy cell leukemia, 37.50% in 16 Langerhans cell histocytosis and 33.33% in 15 other types of leukemia/lymphoma; 5.88% V600E in 34 brain tumor and 11.76% (V600E, V600K, V600L) in 85 other types of solid tumor (GIST, appendix, bladder, adrenal etc.) . None of the 22 endometrial tumor specimens contained the BRAF V600 mutation. The mutation distribution of our data set is in agreement with other published studies. Results could not be obtained in 3.89% specimens due to specimen degradation or low DNA yield. Conclusions: The BRAF gene mutation detection assay using multiplex SNaPshot method is a robust, reproducible, sensitive, economic and fast assay for molecular diagnostic utilization in variety cancers using multiple specimen types. The 2013 CAP/IASLC/AMP joint guidelines call for EGFR/ALK testing in all patients (pts) with stage IV NSCLC with adenocarcinoma components. In 2014 the NCCN guidelines added emerging actionable targets. The adoption rate of guidelines in community practice has not been fully explored for these two sets of guideline endorsements. Methods: Retrospective observational analysis of molecular testing patterns in NSCLC pts treated by 90 community oncologists (15 centers) identified via the COTA Inc database (January 2013 to December 2015). Results: Six hundred and ninety-six pts with stage IV NSCLC (89% adenocarcinoma, 7% NOS, 4% other adenocarcinoma histology) were identified. 449 pts' specimens were sent for both EGFR and ALK per guidelines; of which 38 (8%) were initially marked as insufficient sample size. 16 (42%) pts underwent a second biopsy; resulting in 427 pts (61%) completing both EGFR+ALK testing. 192 pts (28%) were tested for neither EGFR nor ALK. Individually EGFR mutation or ALK fusion testing was performed in 488 (70%) and 443 (64%) respectively. In contrast to guidelines EGFR testing by IHC methodology was performed in 13 (3% of 488) pts. Although testing is guideline recommended irrespective of clinical characteristics, tobacco users were tested less frequently for EGFR (68% smokers tested vs 82% non-smokers, chi-sq p<0.01). EGFR testing rates were similar across gender (M:69% W:71%, p=0.6). Among patients tested for EGFR, the median turnaround-time [TAT] was 22 total days from diagnosis to test reported (range: 2 to 199 days), with 26% of pts receiving results within 10 working days. Testing by NGS for mutations included ROS1: 171 pts (25%), BRAF V600E: 114 pts (16%), MET amp: 96 pts (14%), RET 91 pts (13%), MET exon 14: 80 pts (11%), and ERBB2 69 pts (10%). 69 pts (10%) underwent testing by NGS for EGFR/ALK plus all 6 emerging actionable targets per NCCN, with utilization increasing over time (2013: 3%, 2015: 17%; p < 0.001). 9 of the 69 pts received NGS results within 10 working days. Of the remaining 60 NGS pts with a TAT longer than 10 working days, only 10 pts underwent duplicate rapid EGFR testing. 247 pts were not tested for combined EGFR+ALK (39% of 696): 42 pts had a valid reason for not testing (including early deaths) and 81 pts were not tested and received no treatments. However 124 pts (18%) received chemotherapy without documented molecular testing for EGFR and ALK. Conclusions: Molecular testing guideline adherence in NSCLC is suboptimal (61% tested for combined EGFR+ALK; 18% receiving chemotherapy without testing) in community settings, indicating a need to further educate and explore testing barriers. The planned AMP guideline revision, which will include more actionable targets, will need to take these results into account.

Introduction: Well-characterized formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded (FFPE) quality control materials are critical for the development and implementation of diagnostic tests for solid tumors, as well as for cross-laboratory evaluation in external quality assessment (EQA) schemes. As next-generation sequencing (NGS) becomes more common to parallel test many genes, reference materials containing many variants will be needed to evaluate test performance. However, limited studies have been performed with multiplexed reference materials that challenge the full testing process from nucleic acid extraction to data analysis. Methods: A highly multiplexed FFPE material was developed by a novel method termed FastFFPE, which enabled introduction of 500+ SNPs, insertions and deletions in a single FFPE section. The reference sample of FFPE cells was custom manufactured by Thermo Fisher Scientific (AcroMetrix ) and 10 um scrolls were distributed as aUK National External Quality Assessment (NEQAS) for Molecular Pathology EQA Scheme educational exercise. Laboratories were invited to genotype and submit results to the Scheme, provide methodology details, list genes tested and the levels of detected variants. Results: Each FFPE section contained 555 variants in 53 tumor-associated genes at allelic frequencies ranging from 1% to 17.9% (average 5.3%). DNA extraction followed by PCR indicated that DNA was fragmented similarly to a human tumor FFPE sample. One hundred and one laboratories reported 3,008 test results on 53 different genes, with NGS being the most commonly performed test. In this study, detailed data for NRAS, KRAS, BRAF, EGFR, PIK3CA, KIT and PDGFR was used to analyze sensitivity and specificity. As expected, testing for mutations associated with an increase in cancer was prevalent. A low number of false positives were reported (0.7%); however a number of laboratories did not detect such variants within regions tested. Reported allelic frequencies showed significant variability (e.g., over 10-fold difference in frequency), demonstrating that test methods remain largely qualitative. Conclusions: Use of a highly multiplexed standardized reference sample has successfully enabled laboratories to measure test sensitivity and specificity in-house. Moreover, distribution of a full process FastFFPE material enabled inter-laboratory comparisons of methodologies and limits of detection for the testing of solid tumor variants from nucleic acid extraction to data analysis.
