Introduction: Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) accounts for approximately 85% to 90% of all lung cancers, and a leading cause of cancer death in American. The epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) is a critical part of the signal transduction pathway that controls cell growth and differentiation. EGFR mutations are present in the tumors of 30% to 40% of Asian and 10% to 20% of non-Asian patients with advanced NSCLC. EGFR mutations are more likely to respond to tyrosine kinase inhibitors and have longer median survival than those without EGFR mutations, and identifying mutations in the EGFR gene which are associated with NSCLC can distinguish patients who are more likely to benefit from a targeted therapy. This study compares side-by-side performance of two real-time PCR technologies; Allele Refractory Mutation System (ARMS) and Peptide Nucleic Acid Mediated (PNA-Clamping) in clinical NSCLC samples. Methods: One hundred thirty two (132) formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded (FFPE) samples from NSCLC patients were tested. Tumor tissue was manually micro dissected and DNA extraction was performed using PinPoint extraction kit (Zymo Research). Tumor per cent content was estimated by pathology and was in rnage 30% to 90% for 120 samples and <30% for 12 samples. Method 1: Real-time PCR PANClamp EGFR mutation detection kit (40 mutations) from Panagene. Testing was performed on ABI 7500 Fast instrument from Life Technologies/ThermoFisher, using Peptide Nucleic Acid Mediated Clamping technology. Method 2: Real-time PCR therascreen FDA IVD EGFR RGQ PCR kit (29 mutations) from Qiagen. Testing was performed according to kit insert on Rotor-Gene Q MDx instrument from Qiagen, using ARMS/SCORPIONS technology. Results: A total of 47 EGFR mutations were detected in 41 patients by Method 1, and 47 of EGFR mutations in 43 patients by Method 2 respectively. There was 87.2% (n=41) mutation concordance between Panagene and Qiagen and 12.8% (n=6) were discordant. Panagene EGRF assay missed two mutations and detected 4 extra mutations (after repeat 2 extra mutations did not reproduce). Qiagen EGFR assay missed 2 mutations T790N (testing was repeated twice for these samples). Out of six discordant samples only one had tumor content <30%. Overall correlation between two methods (including results for positive and negative samples n=132) was 95.5 %. Conclusions: Because detection of EGFR mutations qualifies patients for one of the only effective therpies for a disease with an alomst uniformly fatal prognosis, sensitivity is critical. Chromosomal translocations are important for the diagnosis and prognosis of many cancer types. The current gold standard for the clinical detection of translocations, fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH), is low-throughput and cannot identify more than one fusion event at a time. By identifying expressed fusion transcripts, hybrid capture based RNA-sequencing (RNA-seq) can test for numerous translocations simultaneously and may increase the sensitivity of identifying translocations from a heterogeneous tumor sample. We developed a hybrid capture panel for detection of clinically relevant translocations from formalin-fixed paraffinembedded (FFPE) tissue by RNA-seq. Methods: Two cases of ALK rearranged nonsmall cell lung cancer and two cases of Ewing's sarcoma with EWS-FLI1 rearrangements were selected for a pilot study. Both cases were positive for rearrangement by FISH. Capture probes were designed to target the exons of 24 genes commonly rearranged in cancer, resulting in 2308 unique bait sequences and 2x tiling coverage across targets. RNA was extracted from punches of tumor-rich areas in the FFPE block and converted to cDNA using random primers. Strandspecific sequencing libraries were created using dual end-indexes. The resulting libraries were then subjected to 24-hour hybridization with probes, washed, beadpurified, and amplified. Enriched libraries were sequencing using 2x75bp reads on the MiSeq platform. Resulting FASTQ files were aligned to the Hg19 reference genome using STAR v2.4.0d allowing for chimeric reads. Aligned sequence quality control was performed in SAMStat, and coverage efficiency was calculated with BEDtools coverage. Translocations were manually reviewed in the Integrative Genomics Viewer. Results: Across samples, an average of 92% of reads mapped to the Hg19 reference genome. Detection of a translocation was defined as a minimum of 10 on-target chimeric reads per 100,000. By this criterion, translocations were successfully identified in 2 of 4 specimens. Average target coverage efficiency for all probe sequences was 5%, but for sequences of successfully identified translocations, average coverage efficiency was 75% (15-fold enrichment for targets in identified translocations). Conclusions: Hybrid capture RNA-seq can detect fusion events from FFPE tissue. With the potential for greatly increased throughput and decreased cost, hybrid capture RNA-seq may be an alternative to FISH for diagnosing translocations in clinical specimens. Introduction: Next-generation sequencing (NGS) analysis of plasma-derived circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) is a minimally-invasive clinical tool for the serial monitoring of cancer patients because it can detect variants that indicate disease recurrence or the development of drug-resistance. Since these variants can occur at low frequencies and ctDNA is present at low concentrations, development of an assay of this nature is challenging due to the need for increased sensitivity, and high depth of coverage for error correction. Methods: A custom 45 gene panel was developed to detect single nucleotide variants (SNVs) and small indels in cancerrelated hotspots. Plasma was collected from both healthy donors and cancer patients at various treatment stages. Buffy coat was simultaneously harvested for use as a matched normal comparison. Libraries were prepared using 10 ng input with the Kapa Hyper Prep kit (Kapa Biosystems) and custom barcoded adapters. PCR-amplified libraries were captured using a custom xGen Lockdown panel and Universal Blocking Oligos (IDT). To evaluate assay sensitivity, titrations of cell lines with mutations of known frequency were prepared by first Covaris shearing to 150 bp, to approximate the size of ctDNA, and then proceeding with library preparation. Finally, NA12878 cell-line was used to evaluate the efficiency of error correction of the barcoded PCR duplicates. After sequencing, all samples were analyzed using BMF Tools, which is custom software developed for collapsing barcoded PCR duplicates and error correction. Results: Initial results showed that sequencing a 10 ng library of NA12878 at an average raw depth of 106,491x coverage led to an average PCR duplicate family size of 9.0. At an average family size of 9, the sequencing error rat correction Preliminary titration experiments demonstrate an analytical sensitivity of 0.5% mutant allele frequency can be achieve using this method with 10 ng of input DNA. Data from serial draws of cancer patients will also be presented. Conclusions: NGS analysis of ctDNA from plasma can be used to detect somatic mutations to place patients on targeted therapy. Additionally, it can be used serially to detect multiple actionable variants, which is an advantage over single-mutation assays or smaller, more specialized panels. A.S. So, S. Kaplan, S. Gravina, K. Pal Illumina, San Diego CA Introduction Molecular analyses of cell-free DNA (cfDNA), small fragments of circulating DNA extracted from the plasma of blood, provide information on the genetic state of both normal and tumor cells. Due to its non-invasive nature, molecular interrogation of cfDNA is becoming increasingly popular for tumor characterization and monitoring. Indeed, it has been shown that the genetic variants detected in cfDNA are highly concordant with those found in tumor tissue biopsies. To enable molecular analysis of cfDNA, we demonstrate here that Illumina's Research Use Only assay, TruSight Tumor 15 (TST15), designed to assess 15 frequently mutated genes in solid tumors from FFPE samples, can be applied to cfDNA to generate libraries for next-generation sequencing (NGS) for variant detection. Methods: NGS libraries were prepared according to the TST15 protocol using analytical DNA samples that were size-selected to mimic the cfDNA profile. The samples were titrated with various mutations that allowed us to assess the performance of variant detection. Libraries were sequenced on MiSeq instruments and data were analyzed with the TST15 MiSeq Reporter software. Results: Using Illumina's TST15 assay, NGS libraries were successfully generated using analytical cfDNA samples. The libraries passed all TST15 specification metrics, including >93.5% of bases with >500x coverage. Analytical cfDNA were titrated with seven variants at 5% to 6.3% frequency, which approximates the TST15 assay's limit of detection of 5% allele frequency. When sequencing 8 samples on a MiSeq, seven variants were detected in all four replicates (100% sensitivity). Analysis of cfDNA samples titrated with variants at 2.5% to 3.2% frequency resulted in 93% sensitivity. In addition, by modifying filters within the bioinformatics pipeline, several variants at 1% frequency were detected using the TST15 assay.

Introduction: Implementation of plasma-based cell-free DNA (cfDNA) genotyping assays in molecular diagnostics laboratories requires systematic analysis of preanalytic variables that may influence downstream testing. Here, we assess the potential effects of different pre-analytic parameters, such as collection tubes for peripheral blood (PB), time interval from PB to plasma collection, plasma storage temperature, and extraction methods on cfDNA yield, integrity and downstream mutational analysis. Methods: PB specimens from 48 patients were drawn in two different blood collection tubes: K3-EDTA (BD Vacutainer, NJ) and Cell-Free DNA BCT (BCT) (Streck Inc., NE) which prevents release of cellular DNA into plasma by preventing cell lysis. Effect of the time interval from collection of PB to plasma separation at 2, 4 and 16 hrs. The effect of temperature was determined by comparing cfDNA isolation using fresh plasma vs plasma stored at -80 0 C. Comparison of cfDNA yield and integrity by manual cfDNA extraction using QIAamp circulating nucleic acid kit vs automated method using QIAsymphony circulating DNA kit on Qiasymphony was performed by equally splitting plasma samples from the same tube. cfDNA yield and integrity index were measured using Qubit and ALU qPCR, respectively. The Ion Torrent PGM next-generation sequencing platform was utilized to perform downstream mutational analysis of cfDNA samples (n=8) extracted from different collection tubes at different time points using a 50-gene Cancer Hot Spot Panel v2 (Thermo Fisher). Results: Average cfDNA yield at 2, 4 and 16 hrs was 20.3, 23.78 and 41.74 ng/ml in K3-EDTA tubes versus 25.1, 24.04 and 34.2 ng/ml in Streck tubes, respectively (R 2 =0.9200; p<0.0001). DNA integrity index for K3-EDTA tubes ranged from 0.39 to 0.55 whereas it ranged 0.35 to 0.43 for Streck tubes (p=0.01). The average cfDNA yield by manual and automated extraction methods was 12.58 and 11.32 ng/ml, respectively (R 2 =0.9371, p<0.0001). The DNA integrity index range was 0.17-0.55 for the manual method and 0.19 to 0.54 for automated extraction method and therefore similar (p<0.0001). Plasma samples stored at -80 0 C showed lower average cfDNA yield of 26ng/ml compared to 38ng/ml for immediately extracted same samples. Genotyping analysis of cfDNA from two different collection tubes showed 100% concordance for mutant allelic frequency R 2 =0.9483, p value<0.0001 across 8 samples. Conclusions: cfDNA yield and integrity index were comparable for both manual and automated extraction methods. K3-EDTA PB collection tubes did not affect the cfDNA yield, integrity index and downstream applications if plasma was separated within 16 hrs from PB collection, whereas storing plasma at -80 0 C negatively affected cfDNA yield.

Introduction: Clinical molecular diagnostics for gene fusions in cancers has traditionally relied on targeted RT-PCR and/or FISH, robust techniques that are nevertheless limited in scope and scalability. Here we assess the utility of a targeted next-generation sequencing (NGS)-based RNA-seq assay to detect clinically relevant fusions in archival sarcoma specimens. Methods: Clinically-annotated sarcoma cases (n=46) were included in the study, comprising of optimization and validation sets (n=29) of cases with known gene fusions/rearrangements identified in clinical testing, and a discovery cohort (n=17) of cases negative for fusions by such testing. Total RNA extracted from either formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded (FPPE) with RNA integrity number (RIN) values of 2-3 or frozen specimens (RIN 5-9) were used in anchored multiplex PCR-based NGS library preparation with molecular barcoding using the FusionPlex Sarcoma panel (Archer Inc.) targeting 127 exons in 26 genes for agnostic detection of expressed fusions without a priori knowledge of partner genes. Illumina paired-end indexed libraries were sequenced 8-plex on a MiSeq (2x150 bp, v2) and data analyzed on a vendor-provided virtual-machine based analysis pipeline with custom-developed scripts. Results: Optimal libraries were reproducibly prepared from >100 ng of FFPE RNA with a mean of 775,407 total RNA reads and 55,816 unique RNA reads/sample and results were generated within 5 days. Optimization of input RNA, read-lengths, library size were performed to maximize fusion calling sensitivity by the pipeline which accurately detected all known fusions in the optimization and validation sets (29/29=100%), including 4/4 cases with undetected partners of ALK and CIC. Within the discovery cohort, novel and/or unexpected fusions were detected in 6/17 (35.3%) cases, including a targetableTFG-ROS1 fusion (inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor), a rare EWSR1-POU5F1 fusion (undifferentiated sarcoma), a novel EWSR1-FLI1 exons 7:9 fusion breakpoint (Ewing sarcoma), a CIC-DUX4 fusion (undifferentiated sarcoma), and a HAS2-PLAG1 fusion (myxoid lipoblastoma). Cell mixing studies with aEWSR1-FLI1 positive cell line detected the fusion with 253 supporting reads at a 12.5% dilution. Conclusions: The targeted RNA-seq assay offers robust, sensitive and broad detection of targetable and diagnostic gene fusions using minimal and lowquality RNA from FFPE sarcoma specimens within a clinically-relevant time frame. Detection of rare breakpoints and rare gene fusions highlight the utility of unbiased sequencing in capturing the diversity of cancer gene fusions. Enhancing the panel design to target additional fusion genes will improve the clinical utility of this panel. S117. Clinical Reliability and Reproducibility of a Prognostic 31-Gene Expression Profile Test for Cutaneous Melanoma, and Association of the Test with Standard Clinicopathologic Factors R.W. Cook, K. Oelschlager, T. Poteet, D. Maetzold, J. Stone, F. Monzon Castle Biosciences, Inc., Friendswood, TX. Introduction: The majority of metastases and death attributed to cutaneous melanoma (CM) occur in patients who are initially diagnosed with Stage I or Stage II disease. A 31-gene expression profile (GEP) test that provides a molecular classification associated with risk of metastasis has been validated and clinically available since 2013. The test determines a low risk (Class 1) or high risk (Class 2) of metastasis within five years of the primary diagnosis of CM with an area of reduced confidence identified from the true positives and negatives from the training set. This study evaluated the analytical reliability and reproducibility of the 31-GEP test, and reports the association of the risk prediction with standard clinicopathologic factors linked to CM metastasis and death. Methods: Formalin-fixed paraffinembedded tissue from primary melanoma tumors was successfully processed for 6,083 patients from 968 U.S. centers between March 2013 and April 2016 using the 31-GEP RT-PCR-based assay. Metastatic risk class was determined using a proprietary predictive modeling algorithm to compare the cases to an established training set of 164 CM cases. Inter-and intra-assay accuracy and reproducibility were evaluated. Results: Technical success averaged 98%. 82% (4,968) of the cases analyzed were predicted to be low risk Class 1, whereas 18% (1,115) were high risk Class 2. Class prediction was associated with clinical stage, Breslow 2 (p<0.0001 for all, Chi square test). Reproducibility of probability scores was assessed with 21 samples with multiple regression coefficient analysis showing a multiple R 2 of 0. 0.996 ± 0.015 (slope 1.03). Concordance (precision) of proficiency testing and QC samples from 2013 to 2015 (n=164) shows 98.8% concordance with risk classification. The two samples with discordant classification were both within the "reduced confidence" interval for the probability score (i.e., 0.41-0.59). Bland Altman plot showed 95% of variability to be within acceptable limits (not likely to change class assignment). Overall, the tumor content insufficiency rate was 16%, but due to efforts aimed at collaboration with local pathology labs, this improved to 4% for the period of January -April 2016. Conclusion: The 31-GEP test demonstrates robust, reproducible and reliable performance in primary tumor FFPE specimens. Educational efforts in biopsy tissue conservation practices have yielded significant improvements in the rate of tissue received with adequate tumor nuclei content. As expected, high-risk (Class 2) molecular classification was associated with pathologic stage and other morphologic prognostic factors. Introduction: The ability to detect tumor mutations in cell-free DNA from plasma may dramatically change the diagnostic workup of cancer patients, by shifting away from tissue biopsies. One such "liquid biopsy" assay was approved by the FDA in spring 2016. We developed a cfDNA assay using droplet digital PCR (ddPCR) for EGFR mutations in non small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) as part of clinical trials of third-generation inhibitors, followed by translation into our clinical laboratory for routine care of NSCLC patients. Here we present the validation and performance characteristics of this LDT assay in our clinical laboratory. Methods: As part of an IRB-approved study, paired blood samples were collected from 23 consenting patients with advanced NSCLC. All patients had concurrent tumor biopsies available for standard clinical genotyping. Whole blood samples were centrifuged to isolate the plasma fraction within 2 hours of phlebotomy. DNA was isolated using a vacuum manifold with the QIAamp circulating Nucleic Acid Kit. EGFR L858R, exon 19 deletions (ex19del) and T790M mutations were detected in plasma cfDNA using ddPCR (BioRad) with custom primers. In ddPCR, the sample is partitioned into thousands of droplets permitting independent amplification events that are analyzed by flow cytometry. Results: Plasma ddPCR was 95% concordant with results from paired tissue biopsies for EGFR L858R, ex19del, and T790M mutations. Sensitivity and specificity of plasma ddPCR vs tissue testing was .75 (95% CI .22-.99) and 1 (95% CI .22-.99) for L858R, .92 (95% CI .6-.99) and 1 (95% CI .56-1) for ex19del and .87 (95% CI .58-.98) and 1 (95% CI .4-1) for T790M mutations. Concordance with ddPCR performed on paired bloods from 19 samples in a separate laboratory was 100% for L858R and ex19del and 92% for T790M. Precision as assessed by replicate measurements was 100% for L858R, 96% for ex19del and 87% for T790M. Imprecision was highest in samples with low numbers of total PCR events, and the lower limit of the assay was set at 3 mutant in 300 total events. Overall, 3 of 23 (13%) validation samples were insufficient. In the 5 weeks since clinical launch, plasma genotyping has been performed on 15 patients: 4 positive (all initiated targeted therapy), 9 negative, and 2 indeterminate, with a median turnaround time of 4 days from blood draw. Conclusions: ddPCR for detection of actionable EGFR mutations in cfDNA is highly specific relative to tumorbased genotyping. The sensitivity of .72-.92 is in keeping with published reports, likely reflecting biological variations in tumor shedding of cfDNA. Plasma cfDNA genotyping is an appropriate first step for rapid detection of EGFR mutations in NSCLC patients and can eliminate the need for some invasive biopsies.

back_matter.text: M. Al-Kawaaz, T.H. Schwartz, S.B. Omay, H. Fernandes, D. Fernandes Weill Cornell Medicine, New York, NY. Introduction: Craniopharyngiomas are rare benign epithelial tumors that occur along the craniopharyngial duct. Due to their location, they may be locally aggressive and lead to neurologic, endocrinological and/or visual impairment. Two subtypes of craniopharyngiomas are recognized based on age distribution, histopathology, molecular signatures and clinical behavior. We evaluated the utility of molecular characterization to supplement the histological diagnosis of craniopharyngiomas. Methods: Fifty four (54) patients were included in this retrospective study. Histology was reviewed blinded to the mutational status of the tumor. 41 had clear adamantinomatous (C-ADAM) histology, 12 had definitive or probable papillary histology (C-PAP) without diagnostic features of C-ADAM, and 1 showed scant tumor consistent with C-ADAM with an exuberant xanthogranulomatous response. Sanger sequencing was performed for identification of known hotspot variants in the CTNNB1 and BRAF genes. In a subset of cases (n=7), mutational status was detected using a 50 gene next-generation sequencing (NGS) panel that targets hotspots in cancer genes. Results: The cohort included 27 males and 27 females with a mean age of 43 yrs (range 5 to 88 yrs). Twelve (12) cases (22%) harbored a BRAF V600E variant, 35 (65%) demonstrated variants in the CTNNB1 gene, and in 7 (13%) cases no variant was detected. 100% of C-PAP cases harbored the BRAF V600E variant and CTNNB1 variants were detected in 35/41 (85%) of C-ADAM cases. Of those cases in which a mutation was not detected, tumors often demonstrated a cystic morphology and an exuberant inflammatory response, possibly diluting tumor cell content to below a detectable range. One C-ADAM case tested with both Sanger sequencing and NGS, revealed a rare 3 bp inframe deletion of codon 33 in the CTNNB1 gene. Conclusions: The presence of mutations in craniopharyngiomas with adequate cellularity is consistently predicted by histological analysis. Molecular detection of BRAF V600E is useful in confirming a histologic impression of the papillary variant. Tumors of adamantinomatous histology harbored CTNNB1 variants in 85% of the cases. Low neoplastic cellularity in a background of an exuberant inflammatory response may impede the detection of variants in molecular assays. NGS has utility in the identification of rare variants at known hotspots. Finally, molecular characterization should be considered as confirmatory evidence of BRAF mutational status if targeted small molecule inhibitors are to be considered as an adjuvant treatment strategy.

Introduction: Mutation detection in genes such as EGFR and KRAS, along with the detection of translocations is important in the treatment of lung adenocarcinoma. In particular, detection of translocations in ALK, ROS1, and RET have important therapeutic implications. Traditionally, these rearrangements have been detected by FISH, but this methodology provides no information about the fusion partner; however, new assays utilizing next-generation sequencing (NGS) are being offered and provide the advantage of detection of translocations simultaneously with small nucleotide changes. Methods: We have performed clinical testing of over 225 lung cancer samples using the Ion Torrent AmpliSeq RNA Fusion Lung Cancer Research Panel to detect alterations in both RNA and DNA simultaneously. This assay includes PCR primers specific for described breakpoints in ALK, ROS1, RET, and NTRK, along with primers corresponding to genes known to be translocation partners. The assay also includes primer sets for the 3' and 5' regions of each gene (ALK, ROS1, RET, and NTRK) to allow detection of over-expression the 3' end of the gene relative to the 5' end. This calculation may be indicative of a translocation, even in the absence of detection of a specific fusion product. A lung sample identified to have a RET 3' overexpression without detection of a specific fusion was subsequently tested using FISH analysis. A hybrid capture NGS method designed to capture introns in RET, as well as, an RT-PCR assay were also performed on the sample for further confirmation and characterization of the fusion breakpoint. Results: Through the Ion Torrent 3' to 5' imbalance assay, a RET 3' overexpression was detected, but a translocation partner was not identified. FISH analysis using break-apart RET probes was positive for a rearrangement. The translocation was confirmed through DNA hybrid capture NGS as a fusion between exon 13 of FOXP4 and exon 12 of RET. RNA extracted from the sample was amplified using primers designed to these exons were and the reaction produced a product of the appropriate size. Sequencing of this product further confirmed this novel translocation at the identified breakpoint. Conclusions: Next-generation sequencing provides an assay format that can detect both small mutation and rearrangements in tumor. Detection of this FOXP4-RET fusion is novel, to the best of our knowledge. Detection of this novel fusion highlights the necessity of using NGS methods designed to include strategies for detecting not only previously characterized fusions, but novel partners. 1, 2 , H.P. Introduction: Next-generation sequencing (NGS) is increasingly implemented as a diagnostic test to identify actionable mutations in cancer patient samples. However, for routine diagnostics, tumor DNA is extracted from formalin-fixed, paraffinembedded (FFPE) samples, which yields low quantity of damaged DNA. Efforts to amend low starting material through PCR amplification may in turn introduce PCR biases, leading to reduced sensitivity in the detection of copy number alterations (CNAs), an important biomarker for targeted therapy. In short, there is a need for a library preparation platform that performs well with low quality and quantity DNA without relying on massive PCR amplification. Methods: We are here presenting an updated in-solution version of our sequencing platform OS-Seq, which represents a novel technology to sequence low amounts of damaged DNA from a variety of sources including FFPE, plasma, core needle biopsies and fine needle aspirates. OS-Seq uses a repair process based on methods developed to sequence archeological samples (Meyer et al., (2012) , Science, 338 (6104) Our primer sequences are short and isothermic, designed to tile regions of interest at an average spacing of 75bp, and are selected to minimize cross-hybridization or false priming sites. This approach generates accurate sequences without relying heavily on PCR amplification, and therefore has a minimal duplication rate. Results: Using our updated oncology panel of 131 genes, we obtained an on-target rate of up to 73% with fold 80 penalty as low as 3.2 -indicating high efficiency and uniformityand were able to accept DNA inputs as small as 2ng per sample. We demonstrate the sensitivity of our platform through the analysis of dilution series of well-known reference samples, and commercial standards for actionable cancer mutations and CNAs, where a previous version of the platform performed at a level of accuracy comparable to FISH, the gold standard for CNA detection. Conclusions: Importantly, our basic chemistry is easily adaptable to various applications, including targeted exome, whole exome, and whole genome sequencing. were HER2 amplified (Amp), 122 (8.5%) equivocal (Eq), and 1177 (81.7%) were non-amplified (NA). Introduction: Next-generation sequencing (NGS) is becoming a standard for genetic analyses of clinical samples. The DNA retrieved from FFPE tissue specimens is degraded and accurate assessment of quantity and quality is needed for downstream applications such as NGS. We present a SYBR, qPCR-based assay that provides an accurate quantification and DNA degradation score (Dscore), that over performs the standard DNA quantitation methods. It has proved to be efficient in maximizing the success rate of NGS library preparation from clinical FFPE tissue specimens. Methods: Extracted DNA was quantified by five methods: PicoGreen fluorometry, Qubit fluorometer (ThermoFisher Scientific), singleplex Taqman qPCR assay (RNAse P), dual-size TaqMan assay, and a two-probe SYBR Green assay. TaqMan RNase P assay was used as reference method. qPCR was performed on the QuantStudio 6 (ThermoFisher Scientific). NGS libraries were prepared based on the DNA concentration obtained by the quantification method. The libraries yield and quality were assessed by high resolution electrophoresis (Bioanalyzer; Agilent). Results: Data from PicoGreen and RNAse P showed weak correlation (slope = 0.59 and R 2 = 0.37). Qubit showed inconsistent, lower DNA concentrations compared to RNase P across different samples. Small amplicons from dual-size Taqman (QC1) and SYBR qPCR (DS1) assays, showed strong correlation with RNase P (slope = 1.08 and R 2 = 0.86, slope = 0.82 and R 2 = 0.69 respectively), whereas the longer amplicons (QC2 and DS2), showed weak and moderate correlation respectively (slope = 0.70 and R² = 0.36, slope = 0.61 R 2 = 0.13). NGS libraries were prepared based on QC2, DS1, DS2 and RNAse P quantification. Libraries based on QC2 and DS2 had lower yields compared to RNAse P based libraries. DS1 based libraries showed similar or greater yields compared to RNase P based libraries. A clinical laboratory sample submitted for NGS was assayed with the two-probe SYBR assay and identified as highly degraded (Dscore = 226.67). Two libraries were prepared for the sample. The first used DS1-based quantification. The other used 3.6-times more DNA input to compensate for the high Dscore. Very poor library yield was obtained by DS1 quantification. However, considering the DNA degradation and using 3.6 times more DNA, the library provided adequate yield and robust NGS data. Conclusions: Our two-probe SYBR Green-based qPCR assay out-performed four DNA quantification methods for targeted NGS library preparation. It provides accurate data on DNA quality and quantity and helped recover NGS libraries and sequencing data from challenging FFPE clinical specimens. Introduction: Colorectal carcinoma (CRC) is the third most common cancer and the third most common cause of cancer-related death in the United States. Due to a combination of better screening, more effective surgery and innovative therapeutics, both incidence and mortality rates have been falling for the general population in the last 30 years. Because the average age at time of diagnosis is 72, screening normally begins at fifty. Unfortunately, an increase of incidence in people under the age of 50 has been observed over the last a few years, calling this into question. Already, people with known hereditary cancer syndromes and strong family history start screening at earlier ages. Characterizing these patients that are afflicted at such an early age is an important next step in further understanding the risk stratification in populations. Methods: Four patients under the age of 40 with CRC were selected for this study. None of them had microsatellite instability, known familial cancer syndromes or known family history of CRC. Tumor sections were mainly from the primary tumor site, except one from a brain metastasis. Microdissection was used to enrich tumor tissue to >90%. After DNA extraction, whole exome sequencing and subsequent variant calling were performed on the Illumina MiSeq platform. The variants were analyzed against the most significantly mutated genes described in the TCGA molecular characterization of CRC. Additionally, we found 5 patients who is younger than 40 from the TCGA database for a close comparison. Results: Whereas non-synonymous variants, including missense, stop codon gains and frame shifts, were identified in genes related to the common adenomatous pathway (p53, KRAS, APC, etc.), their frequencies were relatively low. In contrast, the C218A>G in CDC27 was found in all four tumors at a frequency of 44.1, 47.6, 55.2, and 85.7%, which results in Tyr73Cys replacement. However, we did not find the same variant in the TCGA samples. Whereas multiple other variants were also found in CDC27, none seemed to be a significant CRC driver. Conclusions: We found a recurrent mutation in CDC27 in all four CRC samples studied. CDC27 is an integral part of the anaphase-promoting complex/cyclosome. Recent studies showed that increased expression of CDC27 caused cells to grow more rapidly. The variant has been cataloged in the COSMIC database as a somatic mutation in both lung and colorectal adenocarcinoma. However, no study has been published yet as to its biological significance. Due to our inclusion criteria and limited by availability of matched normal tissues, our study had pitfalls in small sample size and uncertainty of germline or somatic mutation.

Introduction: Fibrolamellar carcinoma is a translocation-associated carcinoma which affects young patients without underlying chronic liver disease. Our group has shown consistent anterior gradient-2 over expression and loss of LFABP expression in this tumor type. Fibrolamellar carcinoma displays characteristic intratumoral fibrosis. The basis of this extensive fibrosis has not been investigated. The ornithineglutamate-proline pathway is important in providing proline for collagen synthesis and fibrosis. In lower species, this pathway is also important part of the stress response in energy-limited states. We designed this study to evaluate the ornithineglutamate-proline pathway in fibrolamellar carcinoma. Methods: We performed mass spectrometry based proteomics as previously published on 6 formalin fixed paraffin embedded tissue cases of fibrolamellar carcinoma and paired normal tissue evaluating the expression of enzymes involved in the ornithine-glutamate-proline pathway. Similar to a previous publication, this allowed for a semiquantitative assessment of protein levels. The ratio of the level of each protein in the tumor compared to the normal across all six pairs was calculated. Anterior gradient-2 and LFABP were used as internal controls. Each sample was analyzed in duplicate. We validated the results for select markers using immunohistochemistry on another 12 formalin fixed paraffin embedded tissue cases of fibrolamellar carcinoma. Results: Proteomic analysis revealed an increase in the abundance of heat shock related proteins, Hsp 60 and Hsp 90 compared to the paired normal tissue (ratios 1.6 and 1.7). There was also an increase in hypoxia up-regulated protein (ratio =2). There was also overexpression of Ornithine aminotransferase (ratio =36), Pyrroline-5carboxylate synthase (ratio=73.5) and Pyrroline-5-carboxylate reductase (ratio >100) compared to the back ground liver in all cases. There was reduced expression of glutamine synthetase (<0.1). The results for internal controls were appropriate. The net effect of the enzyme changes is an increase in activity in enzymes catalyzing proline synthesis from ornithine and glutamate. Immunohistochemistry confirmed ornithine aminotransferase overexpression in each of 12 cases. Glutamine synthetase was negative in all cases. Conclusions: Fibrolamellar carcinoma shows an increase in hypoxia related proteins indicative of a stress response. The ornithineglutamate-proline pathway shows upregulation of enzymes leading to proline synthesis. This is consistent with the abundant collagen production phenotype of the tumor and may be related to a tumor-related stress response as seen in lower species. Ongoing studies aim to functionally assess the proline biosynthesis pathway. Introduction: Study on genetic information from cell-free (cf) DNA will provide valuable opportunities in cancer research and potentially impact future oncology treatment and diagnosis. As an example, liquid biopsy will provide a non-invasive and cost effective solution for future cancer patient care compared to traditional biopsy tests. Here we report the application of a research-based Ion Torrent nextgeneration sequencing (NGS) Oncomine cfDNA Lung assay and its workflow, which is developed to detect somatic variants at low frequency of 0.1% in cfDNA from plasma. Methods: Twenty-four (24) paired cfDNA were isolated from plasma of research non-small cell lung cancer banked samples (MagMAX Cell-Free DNA Isolation Kit, Thermo Fisher Scientific), and their matched tumor DNA were extracted from formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded (FFPE) tissue (RecoverAll Multi-Sample RNA/DNA Isolation kit, Thermo Fisher Scientific). cfDNA Reference Standards (Horizon Discovery) were used to evaluate assay sensitivity and specificity. Isolated cfDNA and their matched FFPE DNA was "molecularly" barcoded with a set of gene specific primers followed by library amplification. Libraries were then purified with Agencourt Ampure XP beads (Beckman Coulter) and quantified with qPCR (Ion Library Quantitation Kit, Thermo Fisher Scientific). 8 or 16 plex libraries were templated with Ion Chef automated templating instrument (Thermo Fisher Scientific) and sequenced with Ion S5 Sequencing instrument (Thermo Fisher Scientific). Data were analyzed using Torrent Suite Software (TSS). Results: Oncomine cfDNA Lung assay is an Ion Torrent NGS assay targeting 157 Hotspots within 35 amplicons in 11 genes relevant to lung cancer research. The Ion Torrent NGS technology and tailored TSS analytical pipeline allows this assay to detect variants as low as 0.1% limit of detection (LOD). The total process time (from plasma/FFPE specimen to result reporting) could be as short as 32 hours with a total hand on time of 4 hours. Using cfDNA Reference Standards (0, 0.1, 1.0 and 5.0%), 8 known variants were detected with 89.6% sensitivity and 99.8% specificity at 0.1% LOD, 100% (sensitivity and specificity) at both 1.0% and 5.0% LOD. About 20ng of cfDNA and 5ng of FFPE input were tested with Oncomine cfDNA Lung assay test, matched somatic variants were detected at a frequency between 0.28 % to 4.32 % in cfDNA and between 6.85 % to 74.04% in corresponding DNA isolated from FFPE. which can impair PCR, a required process in NGS library preparation. Consequently, library yields and high quality, meaningful sequence data are compromised affecting the confident identification of variants. To overcome these issues, we have used the SureSeq FFPE DNA Repair Mix, which has been optimised to repair a broad range of damage in FFPE-derived DNA, removing artefacts caused by fixation and longterm storage. Methods: We tested the ability of the kit, in combination with a hybridisation-based NGS enrichment panel, the SureSeq Ovarian Cancer Panel. This panel targets seven key ovarian cancer-related genes (BRCA1, BRCA2, ATM, TP53, ATR, NF1 and PTEN). Data presented here are generated from clinical FFPE samples of varying quality (various fragment lengths). Results: We demonstrate that the SureSeq FFPE DNA Repair Mix significantly improves NGS library yields, with an increase of mean target coverage (increased by >2.2 fold), resulting in more meaningful data and therefore confident variant calling. This also permits the use of lower input DNA samples, for example the data generated from a 50 ng sample (treated) was similar to that of a 500 ng untreated sample. We present here a broad range of variants derived from a set of FFPE samples previously studied as part of the GANNET53 trial (metastatic platinum-resistant ovarian cancer, coordinator Nicole Concin, MD) with ranging DNA inputs and sample quality. We have confidently detected variants in the key targeted genes, in particular truncating variants that are likely to have deleterious effects to tumour suppressor genes (e.g., TP53) and DNA repair mechanisms (BRCA1 & 2) for these samples. Conclusions: FFPE remains a challenging sample type, but we have demonstrated significant improvements in NGS library yields preserving original complexity and delivering high-quality sequencing data for confident calling of low frequency somatic variants (<5%). We have comprehensively shown that by repairing the DNA prior to library preparation you can maximise the depth of coverage as well as % bases on target, and therefore increase the sensitivity of the assay without compromising on cost or throughput. Introduction: Single-cell low-pass (LP) whole genome sequencing (WGS) provides an unprecedented view of copy number alterations (CNA) in tumor. A crucial step for application of WGS protocols from limited sources is whole genome amplification (WGA). The highly deterministic nature of the LM-PCR WGA method implemented in Ampli1 kit makes it an ideal candidate for clinical applications were high reproducibility, precision and accuracy are required. Methods: To assess precision and reproducibility of data generated by LP-WGS of libraries from single-cell DNA processed with Ampli1, an average of 500,000 fragments per sample were sequenced from 21 control white blood cells (WBC) from 5 individuals and 8 single cells from 4 aberrant cell lines. The same cells were also analyzed by array comparative genome hybridization (aCGH) using Agilent CGH-array platform (180K) as a reference. To dissect the effect of read depth over accuracy and resolution of CNA calling 2 single cell replicates from an aberrant cell line were sequenced at high coverage (~5 million reads each) and were randomly subsampled at different coverage depths. Accuracy of CNA calling was assessed by ROC analysis using WGS at highest coverage and aCGH data as a reference. Finally to allow the automatic classification of single-cell genomes as aberrant/non-aberrant, a classifier based on support vector machine (SVM) was implemented and trained with "normal" profiles of 21 control WBCs. Results: Results confirmed the high accuracy and precision of the data produced from LP WGS of DNA processed with Ampli1 kit showing a high correlation between spatial distribution of fragments produced from normal WBC control cells and those expected based on position of MseI cutting sites in the genome. Analysis of CNAs from 21 WBCs showed no false positive detected starting from 800.000 reads at a resolution of 500 Kb to 600 Kb. Moreover, the method showed a high accuracy in detecting CNAs from single cells of aberrant cell lines when compared to aCGH at a read number as low as 200,000 reads and at a -based classifier correctly classified 5 normal cells not included in the training set, 8 test cells from 4 cell lines and 11 circulating tumor cells (CTC) isolated by DEPArray from enriched peripheral blood of 2 cancer patients. Conclusions: Ampli1 WGA method proves as a highly precise and accurate method for amplification of single cells for CNA detection by low-pass WGS. The proposed Ampli1 -based LP methodology, together with a SVM-based classifier, provides a robust tool for aberrant cell lines classification and characterization in clinical applications. This work has been performed within IMI CANCER-ID consortium (www.cancer-id.eu). 1212_1217del; N388_Y389del) . Further, kidneys from donors with two APOL1 risk alleles appear to have shorter allograft survival than kidneys from donors with zero or one APOL1 risk alleles. Thus, APOL1 genotyping may have important prognostic consequences. Most APOL1 genotyping methods employ Sanger sequencing. We developed and validated a next-generation sequencing (NGS) assay for qualitative detection of the G1 and G2 APOL1 risk alleles in peripheral blood. Methods: The assay employs APOL1 specific primers with universal tags (M14) to amplify a 238 bp region of APOL1 exon 6 where the G1 and G2 alleles occur. A subsequent PCR incorporates Illumina adapter sequences and patient-specific index sequences. Sequencing is performed on an Illumina MiSeq (2x151bp). Data are processed using in-house developed analysis pipelines. APOL1 variants are interpreted using NM_003661.3. Accuracy and specificity studies were performed on 11 samples that had been Sanger sequenced at a CLIA-certified laboratory, including homozygous G1 (n=2), heterozygous G2 (n=1), G1/G2 compound heterozygous (n=2), and G1/G2 wild-type (n=6). Thirty-six uncharacterized samples (15 from Caucasians, 21 from African Americans) were also tested. Of those, 20 samples were bi-directionally Sanger sequenced at the University of Chicago for confirmation of the NGS results. Reproducibility was assessed both within runs and over different runs on two different sequencers. Barcode carryover was assessed by comparing mutant allele frequencies (MAF) of four constitutional variants of APOL1. Results: Concordance between NGS and Sanger sequencing results was 100% for the 11 reference samples. Of the 36 previously uncharacterized samples, one sample had less than 30 read pairs and was excluded from further analysis. Of the 35 remaining samples, no APOL1 variants were detected in the 14 Caucasian samples and in 10/21 (48%) African American samples. One APOL1 risk allele was detected in 8/21 (38%) samples from African American patients, of which 3/8 (37.5%) were the G1 allele, and 5/8 (62.5%) were the G2 allele. NGS results for 20 of the 35 previously uncharacterized samples showed 100% concordance with the Sanger-based method. Assay reproducibility was 100%. Barcode carryover rate was less than 1%, which is significantly lower than the expected MAF of 50% or 100% for APOL1 risk alleles. Conclusions: NGS is a viable and cost-effective method for APOL1 genotyping and may have important implications for predicting risk of developing kidney disease and renal graft survival.

back_matter.text: Introduction: Targeted cancer therapy based on genomic alterations can be remarkably effective, and has made significant strides with recent advances in nextgeneration sequencing (NGS) technology. DNA isolated from FFPE samples is currently the main source for NGS-based cancer profiling in clinical settings. However, sequencing DNA from FFPE samples is challenging due to limited quantities and poor quality, a result of DNA damage incurred during fixation and storage. Artifacts associated with FFPE DNA have limited the mutation detection Nature Biotechnology 2013), which unfortunately leaves many low-abundant genetic variants of clinical significance undetected. In this study, we investigated the effect of DNA repair and different sample handling methods on the sequencing quality of libraries prepared from FFPE samples. Methods: A repair enzyme mix that is designed to work on a broad range of DNA damage including modified bases, nicks, gaps, and blocked 3' ends, was used to evaluate the effect of DNA repair on NGS library preparation. 100 ng FFPE DNA samples from different types of tumor tissues were treated with the repair mix incorporated into the NEBNext Ultra II DNA library prep workflow and target enrichment using the Agilent SureSelect ClearSeq Comprehensive Cancer Panel. These libraries were sequenced on an Illumina MiSeq and compared to FFPE DNA libraries that were not repaired. Paired-end reads of target-enriched libraries were trimmed using trim_galore and mapped to the human genome (hg19) using bwa-mem. Mapped reads were locally re-aligned using the IndelRealigner from GATKlight. Mismatches were detected using mpileup and the frequency at each position was calculated. Results: DNA repair increased library yields and on-target rates for target-capture for all FFPE samples tested. Extensive analysis of sequencing data showed that SNP and Indel calls were not affected by DNA repair, demonstrating that bias was not introduced during the repair step. Moreover, DNA repair significantly reduced the number of certain low frequency mismatch calls, which are probably artifacts due to DNA damage specific to FFPE samples. Lastly, we observed specific sequencing artifacts associated with methods of handling FFPE samples and have identified effective measurements to avoid such artifacts. Conclusion: DNA repair improves the sequencing quality of libraries prepared from FFPE samples yielding higher on-target rates and lower damage-induced background noise. Moreover, no sequence bias was introduced by DNA repair. We expect that these improvements in the sequencing quality of FFPE samples will ultimately enable more reliable detection of clinically important, actionable mutations at lower abundance.The Journal of Molecular Diagnostics ■ jmd.amjpathol.org based assay (Agena) according to the manufacturer's instructions. Data analysis was performed by using Quantasoft (v1.7.4) (Bio Rad) and MassARRAY Analyzer (MassARRAY). Limit of detection (LOD) studies were performed for both platforms using a serially diluted positive patient sample and the DLD1 cell line. Results: cfDNA yield ranged from 7-117 ng/ml among the tumor types tested. A total of 66 variants detected in matched tumor tissue. On the basis of assay availability, 27/66 expected variants were tested in plasma cfDNA by ddPCR and MassARRAY. 15/27 (56%) mutations were detected in plasma by Bio Rad and MassArray (R 2 =0.9130; p<0.0001). 7/27 variants showed disconcordance between both the platforms. 5/7 mutations (allelic frequency range 0.6-2.10%) were missed by MassARRAY and 2/7 by Bio Rad ddPCR (allelic frequency range 0.6-1.6%). ddPCR turnaround time (4.5 hrs for BioRad ddPCR) was shorter than the MassARRAY system (10 hrs). Repeated studies are in progress to evaluate the discordances between the two platforms. A LOD of 0.1% was observed for both platforms using patient cfDNA samples. Conclusions: ddPCR and the MassARRAY system enable fast and costeffective screening for a targeted set of mutations and can be used for orthogonal validation of next-generation sequencing (NGS) results. Introduction: Gene fusion detection can be critical in the characterization and treatment of a variety of cancers including leukemias and solid tumors. However, the detection of these rearrangements in DNA can be difficult when the common breakpoint sites are not known. Targeted enrichment of RNA, coupled with nextgeneration sequencing, facilitates a far easier method for the identification of gene fusions with minimal a priori knowledge, while still providing valuable information about SNPs, indels, gene and in gene expression. Methods: We applied the NEBNext Direct target enrichment method to the analysis of BRC, ABL1, ALK, RET, and ROS1 transcripts by optimizing bait design for the capture of double stranded cDNA fragments. With this design, short baits specific to the 3' and 5' ends of the target transcript regions were used, enabling the capture of gene fusions in which only one fusion partner is known. RNA from several cell lines containing known gene fusions were converted into double stranded cDNA with a subsequent 90minute hybridization to anneal baits. The baited cDNAs of interest were captured on streptavidin beads, off target sequence was removed and Illumina-compatible adaptors were added which incorporated both a sample ID for multiplexing and unique molecular IDs for PCR duplicate filtering. Results: MiSeq generated PE150 reads were aligned to human B38 using STAR with 90% of the reads mapping to the target regions. Fusions of ALK, RET, and ROS1 with untargeted genes were detected with Star-Fusion, as well as BCR-ABL fusions in which both genes were targeted. All fusions that were detected in libraries generated from 200 ng of total RNA were also detected in libraries generated from only 50 ng of total RNA, and all but one fusion was detected from libraries prepared with only 25 ng of total RNA. Conclusions: Applying the NEBNext Direct target enrichment method to cDNA derived from RNA samples enabled the generation of targeted RNA-Seq libraries in one day with 90% of the reads on target. The high specificity of the method, the use of a single bait per target fragment, and the incorporation of unique molecular IDs enables the detection of low frequency gene fusions, even when the fusion partner is not known. Introduction: An NGS mutation panel for AML was tested for clinical validation using 24 formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded (FFPE) tumor AML samples selected from laboratory archives. Specific targets for this validation study are CEBPA, KIT, FLT3 D835 (ITD not covered), and NPM1. Methods: Horizon Diagnostic Tru-Q HDx samples were used to establish run and sample level thresholds prior to sequencing 24 AML FFPE patient samples with previously known variants. DNA from 6 patient samples was purified using four different FFPE DNA purification systems and compared according to yield, quality by qPCR, and sequencing to determine optimal performance in the NGS assay. Forty eight (48) NGS libraries were prepared from the 24 patient FFPE samples using the Ion AmpliSeq Library Kit 2.0 and primers from the Ion AmpliSeq AML Research Panel, covering 237 amplicons over 19 genes. Sequencing was performed on the Ion Torrent PGM1.1. Base-calling, sequence alignment, variant analysis, and sequencing quality control were performed using vendor software (Torrent Suite 5.0, GenomOncology Workbench) and analysis workflows. Results: Horizon sample variants were detected with a minimum variant allele frequency (VAF) of 3%, 100% positive predicted value (PPV), mean depth of >3309X, 166 true positive variants, and 88.24% on-target reads. Sample DNA was isolated using Qiagen QIAamp FFPE Tissue Kit due to performance QC metrics and low number of false negative variants. The Ion AmpliSeq AML Research Panel generated >769X coverage for 62.07% of the targeted bases in the FFPE AML samples per 318 chip. Ion AmpliSeq AML Research Panel detected 57% (31/54) total known mutations; confirming 80% of known NPM1 (n=20), 18% of known FLT3 D835 (n=16), 66% of known KIT (n=6), and 66% of known CEBPA mutations (n=12). NPM1 was the most frequently sequenced gene in this AML validation study (n=10 patient samples). Conclusions: Clinically relevant NGS data can be obtained for select AML associated genes: KIT and NPM1; FLT3 and CEBPA have significant drop-out regions of coverage. FFPE blood clot samples yielded low quality DNA, making reliable and robust clinical applications challenging. To increase variant detection, alternative assay designs and/or sequencing platforms need to be evaluated. Performance overall was limited due to sample input and inherent limitations to detecting large indels.

back_matter.text: J. Kemppainen, J. Wisotsky, B. Hall, G. Latham Asuragen, Austin, TX. Introduction: Liquid biopsy (LBx) specimens have emerged as a potential alternative to solid tissue biopsies. Circulating cell-free DNA (ccfDNA) can be detected in most advanced tumors using methods such as next-generation sequencing and digital PCR. Actionable ccfDNA, however, requires efficient sample prep to detect low-abundance variants. Several kits for extracting ccfDNA are available but few studies have rigorously quantified recoveries and assessed fragment size bias across these different methods. We evaluated 8 on-market ccfDNA isolation kits for recovery of multiple endogenous and exogenous targets of various fragment lengths. Methods: Human plasma from 19 healthy volunteers was collected on different days, double-spun to remove blood cells, and frozen at -80°C. For processing, 1 ml aliquots were either isolated directly or spike-in controls were added prior to processing. All samples were processed according to the manufacturer protocol and eluted in 50 ul. Exogenous spike-in controls included DNA templates from 102 to 1007 bp in length. Endogenous DNA was assessed across multiple gene loci. Quantitative PCR was used to measure the abundance of specific genomic DNA targets, and the Bioanalyzer (Agilent) and Qubit (Thermo) was for bulk DNA. Time-motion analyses of kit workflows were also performed. Results: Within the ccfDNA isolation methods, yields were statistically indistinguishable across different plasma donors and operators. Across methods, the kits segregated into two groups of significance by yield. The top group extracted about twice as much endogenous DNA, with a range of 2300-3300 cp (qPCR, multiple reference genes), 7 to 11 ng (Bioanalyzer, 50 to 2000 bp fragments), and 7 to 10 ng (Qubit) per ml of plasma. Recovery of exogenous spike-ins of <200 bp DNA was typically <25% and resulted in yields that maintained the hierarchy of kit performance observed from endogenous DNA. No difference in performance was observed comparing column and magnetic beads, especially those with silica chemistry. Processing times for manual workflows ranged from 1.5 to 3 hrs for a batch of 12 samples. Conclusions: The relative performance of the top kits was similar for different endogenous reporters and across different exogenous reporters. Silica-based chemistries were common to several of the top performing filter and bead isolation kits. However, the poor absolute recovery of exogenous DNA with similar size to ccfDNA suggests opportunities to improve LBx sample prep and increase the number of samples that can be analyzed, along with the sensitivity of downstream variant detection.

Kanagal-Shamanna M.D. Anderson Cancer Center, Houston, TX. Introduction: TP53 mutation can be used as a minimal residual disease (MRD) marker in patients with both hematological and solid tumors. In chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), detection of low-level subclonal TP53 mutations prior to chemotherapy predicts treatment resistance/ relapse. Currently available sensitive hotspot-based mutation detection techniques, such as digital PCR, are suboptimal for TP53 as mutations span the entire coding region. At the same time, nextgeneration sequencing (NGS) based profiling using multi-gene panels adopted by most clinical labs is not cost-effective for repeated monitoring of a single gene in follow-up samples. These limitations can be circumvented by using "single-gene" NGS-based assay at a high coverage for low-level mutation detection. Here, we describe an amplicon-based sensitive NGS-based TP53 (Accel TP53) assay using Miseq validated in a pre-CLIA laboratory Methods: We retrieved archived bone marrow DNA samples from 27 CLL cases with known TP53 mutations detected by NGS using the amplicon-based custom-modified Illumina TruSeq Hotspot Panel that includes 53 cancer related genes. Cohort included samples with a TP53 mutant allelic frequencies (MAF) ranging from 1.3% to 90.8%; 18 samples had TP53 mutations with <5% MAF. Genomic DNA (40 ng) was used for library preparation using Accel TP53 Panel (Swift Biosciences) consisting of 21 amplicons (average size, 140 bp) covering the entire coding region (1.8 kbp) . Quantified barcoded libraries were pooled and sequenced (27 samples/run) on Miseq using 300V2 micro flow cell. Data analysis was performed using a custom bioinformatics pipeline based on Lofreq, GATK and Pindel for variant calling at 1% MAF and 250X coverage filter. Results: Twenty-seven samples/ flow cell on Miseq generated an average cluster density of 480K/mm 2 with coverage of 2000X per sample. Using a cut-off of The Journal of Molecular Diagnostics ■ jmd.amjpathol.org amplified and sequenced using this method with a combined alignment average of 630,000 reads (almost 3000X average coverage). Five of the 8 "inadequate" specimens were compared with their alternatively tested specimens with adequate DNA and all sequence results matched. In one of 5 samples, a clinically actionable mutation (KRAS p.G12D) was identified. No mutations were detected in the 3 of 8 samples that had minimal DNA sufficient only for automated analysis. Hands-on technician time was reduced by 2.5 hours per sequencing run. Conclusions: Use of the Ion Chef for automated NGS processes generates data that is comparable to manual methods in a time-efficient manner. In addition, specimens that were deemed inadequate for manual library preparation, could be successfully analyzed using this two-chip combined data method.

back_matter.text: S. Roy-Chowdhuri, M.J. Routbort, R.R. Singh, R. Broaddus, A.J. Lazar, A. Rashid, H. Chen, A. Yemelyanova, J. Manekia, W. Chen, L.J. Medeiros, S.R. Hamilton, R. Luthra, K.P. Patel MD Anderson Cancer Center, Houston, TX. Introduction: Pooling of sequencing libraries for next-generation sequencing (NGS) analysis represent a major change from the conventional practice of physically separating patient samples. Simultaneous handling and pooling pose a potential risk of sample crossover during pre-analytical and analytical steps. Library barcodes allow multiplexing of multiple samples within a single analysis run of a targeted NGS panel, but do not provide a way to identify sample mix-ups. In contrast, single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNP) haplotypes can be combined to generate a unique signature that can be used as a patient identifier (ID) for error reduction. In this study, we reviewed the utility of a SNP ID panel as a patient safety tool in NGSbased mutation testing. Methods: We retrospectively reviewed 11,076 consecutive solid tumor specimens analyzed by NGS, including 9913 tumor only cases on a hotspot-based panel and 1163 paired tumor/normal (T/N) cases on expanded panels. All panels included the Ion AmpliSeq Sample ID Panel containing 8 primer pairs that target unlinked SNPs with high minor allele frequency across a very diverse group of human population and an additional primer targeting amelogenin with a 6 base pair deletion in X-chromosome for gender determination. The SNP ID code is automatically generated, starting with either F or M for gender determination and the remaining letters represent the genotype of the sample at each SNP, thus providing a unique sample ID allowing comparison of samples within a run or between runs. Results: A total of 5 sample errors were detected by the SNP ID panel in pre-signout quality review in 11,076 NGS cases. Of the 9913 tumor only cases, 2 sample errors were identified due to identical SNP IDs and mutation profiles on samples from the same run. Of the 1163 T/N paired cases, 3 sample errors were identified from mismatched SNP IDs. Root cause analyses revealed that the errors occurred at the DNA extraction (n=3) or dilution (n=2) steps and involved samples that were either physically juxtaposed or carried sequential accession numbers. Repeat extraction and analysis resolved the issue in each case preventing any harm to the patients. Corrective actions and safety checks were implemented for prevention of such errors in the future. The SNP ID panel provided highly accurate sample identification for paired T/N samples from the same patient as well as longitudinal studies using multiple samples from the same individual. Conclusions: The rate of sample identification error in NGS analysis appears to be low when standard laboratory practices are followed. Potential sample identification errors resulting from human error in a high-volume laboratory may be prevented by utilizing SNP ID genotyping for sample identification. Introduction: Detection of the JAK2 V617F mutation is important in the diagnosis and prognostic risk assessment of myeloproliferative neoplasms (MPNs). Methods designed to detect this variant have also been used to monitor patient response to therapy. This study evaluates the use of digital droplet PCR (ddPCR) for the detection of JAK2 V617F in blood and bone marrow using RainDance Digital PCR technology. Methods: The RainDance Digital PCR technology utilizes isothermal mechanical shearing of genomic DNA, avoiding potential damage to nucleic acid that can occur due to heating which is used in chemical fragmentation methods. In addition, this technology generates greater than seven million droplets per specimen allowing for direct data analysis that does not require the application of Poisson statistics. Each droplet generated by the RainDrop Source containing a single molecule of fragmented DNA then undergoes PCR amplification utilizing fluorescently labelled probes designed to detect either the wild-type JAK2 V617V sequence or the mutant JAK2 V617F sequence. After amplification, the RainDance Sense instrument counts droplets expressing either wild-type fluorescence, variant fluorescence or no fluorescence. RainDance Analyst Software II then quantitates the level of JAK2 V617F expression in that specimen. Results: Over 100 DNA specimens were tested including 50 samples that had been previously assessed for the JAK2 V617F mutation via alternate testing methods, 10 samples from normal healthy donors, and 40 additional samples for monitoring therapeutic response. In addition, two JAK2 V617F positive cell lines, (SET2 and HEL), and a JAK2 V617F negative cell line, (MV4-11), were used to determine the limit of detection and limit of blank for the variant. This approach is capable of detecting JAK2 V617F with high sensitivity, specificity, and repeatability down to detection levels of <0.1% mutant DNA. This ddPCR method has qualitative concordance with alternative methods including: Sanger sequencing of cfRNA from plasma, NGS of DNA by both amplification and hybrid capture methodologies, and qPCR; as well as quantitative concordance with NGS and qPCR. Analysis of DNA from patients with specimens from multiple time points spanning from diagnosis through course of treatment reveals that this technology can provide a sensitive method for tracking therapeutic response. Conclusions: When additional factors such as speed, ease of use, and cost are considered the RainDance Digital PCR technology provides a fast, accurate and cost effective method for detection of JAK2 V617F for the diagnosis of MPN and for use monitoring treatment response.

back_matter.text: H. Jung, G.J. Tsongalis, J.A. Lefferts Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center, Lebanon, NH. Introduction: The OncoScan FFPE assay is a cancer diagnostics tool for detecting genome-wide copy number alterations in formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded (FFPE) solid tumor specimens. The assay requires a DNA concentration greater than 12 ng/uL for the recommended 80 ng input. Often extracted DNA concentrations can be much lower than needed. This results in higher rates of samples that are not tested (quantity/quality not sufficient, QNS) and/or internal QC failure when testing is attempted. Here we report a procedure for concentrating samples to reach the desired amount of input DNA for the OncoScan assay. Methods: Genomic DNA samples were extracted from FFPE tissue samples using the QIAamp DNA FFPE Tissue kit. The amount of DNA was quantified and samples with less than 12 ng/uL were selected for a concentration procedure. Uncapped DNA samples were incubated at 55°C for 2 hours to completely evaporate the solvent and then the appropriate amount of nuclease-free water was added for the required concentration. If the amount of DNA was too low to reach the target concentration, 6.6 uL of nuclease-free water was added. Effects of the concentration procedure were determined by comparing the quality control metrics provided by the OncoScan assay. Results: During a three-month period (from July 2015 to October 2015), we received 38 solid tumor specimens (19 melanocytic lesions and 19 glioma cases) for the OncoScan assay. DNA with concentrations greater than 12 ng/uL was extracted from 22 (57.9%) specimens and 16 (42.1%) specimens generated less than 12 ng/uL. Following the OncoScan assay, 71.1% of the samples generated QC-pass results; whereas the remaining samples failed to pass QC or were rejected due to QNS. During the subsequent six-month period (from November 2105 to May 2016), 54 melanocytic and 36 glioma cases were submitted. Among these 90 specimens, only 36 (40.0%) yielded greater than 12 ng/uL. Following our concentration procedure, the number of samples with the target concentration increased to 70 (77.8%). This procedure resulted in more samples being suitable for testing with the recommended amount of DNA (80 ng) compared to before implementing the sample concentration procedure (57.9%). Accordingly the rates of QC-pass significantly increased to 90.0%, and no samples were rejected for QNS. Interestingly, DNA amounts as low as 15 ng generated QC-pass results. Conclusions: Implementation of our simple yet effective concentration procedure resulted in OncoScan test results of higher quality than obtained previously. Using the correct amount of input DNA is critical to improved performance characteristics. This concentration procedure also increased the chances of obtaining analyzable results from samples with very low amounts of DNA.
back_matter.section: TT79. Concentration of Genomic DNA Is Critical for the OncoScan FFPE Assay

back_matter.text: Poor Quality of DNA J. Plambeck, A. Cushman-Vokoun, W. Zhang, J.A. Bridge, T.C. Greiner University of Nebraska Medical Center, Omaha, NE. Introduction: Most laboratories have implemented quality control standards for interpreting next-generation sequencing (NGS) data, one of which is obtaining a minimum number of reads per amplicon. If the threshold is not met over multiple amplicons, (e.g., 500X coverage), the sample may be judged inadequate for sequencing or the results are reported with limitations of the genes with low reads. Analysis of the coverage pattern for the amplicons can lead to the identification of genes that have very high amplification that may reduce the number of reads for other genes in the panel. We present an index case with MET amplification. A second case is shown to illustrate how our modified review of amplicon coverage, employed after the index case, identified another targetable amplified gene. Methods: A pelvic tumor from a 67 yo male with a prior ureteral carcinoma was extracted and sequenced using the Ion Torrent 50 gene Ion AmpliSeq Cancer Hotspot Panel v. 2.0, the Ion One Touch 2 and the Ion Torrent Personal Genome Machine (PGM). Sequence data were analyzed using the Torrent Suite Software v4.0.2 with the Variant Caller plugin v 4.0, to identify adequate coverage for detecting somatic mutations. The second case, similarly extracted and sequenced, consisted of a colorectal carcinoma metastatic to the liver in a 51 yearold man. Results: In case one, 13 of 50 genes were judged to have inadequate read coverage (<500X) and the specimen was initially considered inadequate for NGS. Review of the reads per gene and the coverage overview plot showed that one gene (MET) had a very high coverage of 57,000 reads. MET amplification is known to occur in tumors, but is unknown in primary ureteral tumors. Therefore, fluorescent in situ hybridization analysis (FISH) was performed with MET probes, which demonstrated MET amplification (avg. of 54.4 signals/cell). Our modified laboratory operating protocol for review of amplicon coverage identified a second patient that was found to have very high reads of ERBB2 (HER2) at 70,000 reads, and amplification was confirmed by FISH analysis (avg. of 26.3 signals/cell), in the colorectal carcinoma. Conclusions: Laboratories could unnecessarily call a specimen inadequate for NGS analysis if they only review the number of genes with low read coverage. Reviewing coverage of all of the genes will identify cases with amplification of key targetable genes such as MET and ERBB2, thereby prompting secondary analysis by FISH or cytogenomic array. A.I. Wald, M. Tolino, M. Barbi de Moura, M.N. Nikiforova University of Pittsburgh Medical Center, Pittsburgh, PA. Introduction: The Ion Chef instrument offers hands-off automated template preparation, template enrichment, and sequence chip loading for NGS on Ion Torrent platforms. We evaluated the performance of the Ion Chef for use in a high-volume clinical NGS laboratory. Sequencing results obtained from the Ion Chef preparation were compared to manual preparation for DNA and RNA AmpliSeq libraries. Methods: Total of 24 DNA and 3 RNA AmpliSeq libraries were prepared for sequencing on the Ion Proton using either manual approach (OneTouch2, OneTouch ES, and manual chip loading) or automated approach (Ion Chef (Fisher Scientific)). Sequencing run metrics, barcode mapping quality, percent on-target mapping, and variants (single nucleotide variants (SNVs), indels, copy number alterations (CNAs), and gene fusions) were compared between preparations. Repeatability and reproducibility were performed by sequencing three libraries generated from the same starting DNA on three different Ion Chef/Proton runs by different technologists. Results: The NGS runs prepared using the Ion Chef showed more filtered low quality reads compared to the manually-prepared NGS run (13-42% on Ion Chef versus 6-9% manual). The loading and usable sequence were comparable between manual and Ion Chef preparations (90% loading, 60% usable sequence for manual versus 88% loading, 54% usable sequence for Ion Chef). Percent on-target mapping were concordant between Ion Chef and manual runs (83%, SD=0.5). Overall, 190/191 (99.5%) known variants (178 SNVs, 13 indels), 18/18 (100%) CNAs, and 3/3 (100%) gene fusions were correctly detected with the Ion Chef preparation. Reproducibility and repeatability demonstrated concordant variant frequencies and coverages over all three runs. Conclusions: Automated Ion Chef template preparation and chip loading produces comparable data in regards to detection of SNVs, indels, CNAs, and gene fusions compared to manual preparation. It allows for a complete automated, hands-off approach improving productivity of the laboratory in a high volume setting. D. Biliti, M. Amin, S. Britton William Beaumont Hospital, Royal Oak, MI. Introduction: Decalcification solutions contain strong acids which are harsh on tissues and damage the DNA. Milestone has created a proprietary 10% EDTA solution called Mol-Decalcifier to decalcify bone specimens in 16 hours and still allow for molecular testing. This study is designed to explore the effects of Mol-Decalcifier on bone core biopsies, H&E staining quality and molecular testing (PCR and FISH). Methods: Different batches of formalin-fixed bone core biopsies were tested with this decalcification procedure. Biopsies were obtained and placed into 10mL of preheated Mol-Decalcifier. A Shaking Bath was used to maintain 37°C with concomitant agitation. Biopsies were removed from the decal solution after the assigned time intervals (range 2 to 30 hours) and rinsed in water for 30 minutes. All biopsies were routinely processed thereafter to create paraffin blocks. All biopsies were evaluated for ease of microtomy sectioning and quality of H&E stained sections. We tested for DNA viability with FISH and PCR testing. Results: Twentytwo hours was determined as the maximum amount of decalcification time using Mol-Decalcifier and still have viable DNA for PCR, but not for FISH. Less DNA was retrieved if decalcified longer than 22 hours. We successfully attempted both PCR and FISH testings for decalcification times of 12-16 hours. Decalcification for less than 12 hours affected the microtomy sectioning as tissue was incompletely decalcified. Conclusion: A decalcification technique that peserves DNA integrity is a critical need at this time. By implementing the use of Mol-Decalcifier for all bone core biopsies, the pathologist will have to contend with increased turnaround times for biopsy diagnoses. A decalcification technique that preserves the DNA integrity is an essential need in the current era of molecular testing. Radiologist prefer to biopsy bone as compared to visceral organs (such as lung and liver) as this is likely to have the least clinical complications.
