back_matter.text: T.L. Gallagher, F. Blumental de Abreu, F. de Abreu, W.A. Wells, G.J. Tsongalis Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center, Lebanon, NH. Introduction: The PerkinElmer LabChip GX Touch 24 instrument (GX) automates gel electrophoresis via a microfluidic chip. The DNA Extended Range LabChip is comprised of a set of interconnected microchannels that join a separation channel and buffer wells. The LabChip is primed to fill the microchannels of the chip with a gel-dye matrix and buffer. A short capillary draws sample from a microplate well by negative pressure. The sample passes through the chip microchannels through the matrix by electrophoresis. A sizing ladder incorporates with the sample during electrophoresis providing an internal mechanism for quantification and sizing. As the nucleic acid fragments are sieved by size in the central channel, a laser excites the fluorescently-dyed molecules present within the gel matrix. The fluorescence intensity is plotted against time to generate an electropherogram for each sample. Data can also be visualized as a virtual gel similar to agarose gel slabs or obtained in tabular format. For this validation, we performed limit of detection (LOD) and precision on the LabChip GX Touch 24. Methods: DNA extractions were obtained from FFPE samples using the QIAamp DNA FFPE kit in conjunction with the QIAcube instrument. This validation employed the DNA Extended Range LabChip and DNA 1K Assay kit with the GX as recommended by the manufacturer. An internal control positive for 15 bp deletion in exon 19 of the EGFR gene was included in each run. LOD assessed the amount of amplicon necessary for detection of PCR reactions from non-diluted to 1:25 dilutions. Minimum template input for the PCR assay was also evaluated using serial dilutions from 0.22 ng to 14 ng to determine limit of detection. Precision was evaluated by running positive and negative samples on two independent runs. Results: The PerkinElmer LabChip GX Touch 24 is capable of sample fragment separation with minimal starting template (0.22 ng). Reproducibility or the lack of inter-assay/within-assay variability was demonstrated when identical calls (100% precision) were made for the positive and negative samples on two independent runs. Conclusions: This validation demonstrates how the GX reduces separation time and accurately sizes nucleic acid fragments using volumes as low as 10 microliters to yield quantification data of samples. When compared to other capillary electrophoresis instruments, the GX also provides precise and accurate calls. Introduction: RNA-seq on poly-A+ RNA, the current standard for whole transcriptome sequencing (WTS) is a comprehensive method for transcriptome profiling that is limited in its application to formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded (FFPE) specimens due to the requirement for high-quality RNA. Here we assess the diagnostic utility of exome-capture transcriptome sequencing (CTS), a hybridizationbased enrichment method for profiling the protein-coding transcriptome in degraded RNA from archival FFPE tumor specimens. Methods: CTS libraries were prepared with 40 ng of RNA (RIN 2-3) from FFPE specimens (n=20) known to harbor pathogenic somatic mutations and gene fusions. Following second-strand synthesis and hybridization to the VCRome 2.1 exome-capture probeset (NimbleGen) to enrich for the coding transcriptome, paired-end sequencing (2x100bp) was performed at 4-plex on an Illumina HiSeq. Reads were aligned to GRCh37 using STAR v2.3.0e and quality metrics generated using RNA-SeQC. Gene fusions were called with deFuse v.0.6.1 and SOAPfuse and known mutations from whole-exome sequencing (WES) were genotyped for expression. Diagnostic sensitivity and metrics were benchmarked against matched poly-A+ WTS libraries (n=16) sequenced 2-plex on a HiSeq and prepared from 500 ng of total RNA (RIN 7-10) from fresh-frozen specimens. Results: Adjusted for lane multiplexing, CTS libraries showed comparable total paired-end reads/sample (CTS: median 90.8x10 6 and WTS: median 97.1x10 6 ) and read mapping rates (CTS 97.8%; WTS 97.2%). Library complexity with much lower RNA input in CTS (40 ng) were comparable to WTS libraries prepared with 500 ng of RNA (unique rate of mapped reads 65.8% and 64.8% for CTS and WTS, respectively).The combined nominated set of fusions from two independent fusion callers correctly identified the expected gene fusions in 20/20 (100%) of CTS libraries prepared from FFPE tumor specimens; in comparison, 15/16 of matched WTS libraries from frozen specimens were positive for the expected fusion. Normalized to library size, supporting read counts for fusions, and exonic read coverage rates were both significantly higher (p<0.05) in CTS libraries compared to WTS. In 9 samples on which both CTS, WTS, and WES was performed, variant calling to detect expression of somatic SNVs revealed a concordance rate of 34/50 variants between CTS and WTS, with five variants identified only on CTS. Conclusions: CTS is a powerful and robust technique for unbiased genome-wide characterization of the coding transcriptome in low-quality RNA from archival FFPE specimens with high sensitivity in detecting fusions and somatic SNVs comparable to standard poly-A+ WTS. CTS has significant potential to facilitate both translational research and clinical diagnostics on FFPE specimens. N. Aggarwal, M. Miller, C.L. Burnes, M.N. Nikiforova, S. Roy Univeristy of Pittsburgh Medical Center, Pittsburgh, PA. Introduction: Copy neutral loss of heterozygosity (CNLOH) is seen in a subset of hematologic malignancies and often has clinical implications. Unlike conventional karyotyping and Fluorescence in-situ hybridization, single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) array-based methods can reliably detect CNLOH. This presents a unique challenge for validation of CNLOH using orthogonal methods and most people rely on validating the calls using a different SNP array based platform. Currently, there is no published data or guidelines for clinical validation of CNLOH. We present our experience of clinical validation of CNLOH using PCR-based LOH analysis. Methods: Bone marrow/ peripheral blood samples from 9 cases (myeloid neoplasms-8 and chronic lymphocytic leukemia-1) with at least one CNLOH detected by CytoScan HD (Affymetrix, Santa Clara, CA) SNP array were used for clinical validation. The raw signal data (CEL files) were processed and annotated using the Chromosome Analysis Suite (ChAS v3.0) software. For confirmation, the targeted regions were subjected to PCR-based LOH analysis. Multiple loci in region of interest were amplified. LOH testing was performed by fragment analysis on the ABI3730 DNA Analyzer using GeneMapper Software v5.0. LOH was determined using the formula (NL / NS)/ (TL/TS) (N=Normal Tissue, T=Tumor Tissue, L=Long Allele, S=Short Allele) and reported as LOH when allelic ratio for a particular marker was below 0.5 or above 2.0. When normal tissue is not available, average blood value ratios are used. Results: The cases had CNLOH involving the following loci: 1p, 7q, 13q, 17p and 18q. All CNLOH were telomeric with minimum size of 25 megabases by SNP array analysis. Presence of LOH was confirmed in 7/9 cases using PCR-based analysis. Of the two cases that could not be confirmed, one (CLL case) had a large 13q CNLOH by SNP array but a normal allelic pattern by the PCR analysis. This is likely due to a very small concurrent homozygous deletion at 13q14 which included the PCR primer binding site and the PCR results likely reflect the preserved alleles from the non-neoplastic cells. The second had a 7q CNLOH but demonstrated single allelic peak in PCR LOH assay, which may either reflect true somatic LOH or non-discriminatory alleles in the patient's germline DNA. Due to the lack of a paired normal sample, the true status could not be confirmed. Conclusions: In summary, CytoScan HD SNP array platform can accurately detect CNLOH in hematologic neoplasms. PCR-based LOH analysis method is a reliable method for validation of CNLOH alterations. Limitations include the presence of concurrent homozygous deletions and absence of paired normal samples to ascertain LOH status using PCR-based methods. Introduction: Translocations/fusions involving the genes ALK, RET, and ROS1 are rare but recurrent findings in lung adenocarcinomas. The prevalence of these fusions in adenocarcinomas is variable, with ALK fusions at 3% to 5%, followed by RET and ROS1 at 1% to 2%. Though rare, these fusions are clinically relevant as they may be targeted via specific tyrosine kinase inhibitors. Each of these genes may be fused to a variety of different partners, complicating their detection by methods other than FISH. Creating assays capable of detecting these anomalies at low levels in RNA from formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded (FFPE) tissue has been historically challenging. Methods: Libraries were prepared by first extracting RNA (QIAGEN) from FFPE followed by reverse transcription and multiplex PCR amplification by a set of PCR primers designed by the OncoNetwork Consortium (Life Technologies), followed by library preparation (Kapa Biosystems) and MiSeq sequencing (Illumina). The primers target 5 housekeeping control genes, 6 control amplicons for the purpose of detection of non-targeted fusions via analysis of 3'-5' expression ratios and 43 primer pairs test for a larger set of unique ALK, RET, and ROS1 fusion genes. Data analysis was performed using in-house developed bioinformatics pipelines. Limited by the number of positive samples, 43 synthetic oligonucleotides (IDT) were used in spike-in experiments to test the effectiveness of the assay's 43 primer pairs (one per unique primer pair) via mixing into negative cDNA following reverse transcription at various concentrations. Results: Out of 36 negative and 9 positive previously tested FFFPE samples we observed 100% concordance. Synthetic spike-ins for each component primer pair were identifiable at both 10000 and 2000 copies per reaction intended to simulate fusion positive cases at average and low copy number levels. Dilution studies of fusion positive RNA (N=2) into negative RNA showed sensitivity to a limit of ~1% tumor cells. Inter (N=7) and intrarun (N=8) reproducibility was 100%. For 3':5' expression signal ratios: 93% of ALK fusions and 100% of ROS1 fusions were detected at a cutoff ratio of 1.0, and 100% of RET were detected at 40. Conclusions: We demonstrate that the OncoNetwork primer set coupled with Illumina sequencing delivers excellent clinical performance for detection of ALK, RET and ROS1 fusion sequences. Highly efficient detection of low-level signals indicates this may be a superior method compared with FISH and other NGS methods for low tumor percentage samples. Novel fusions may also be identified by detecting 5':3' bias, with reflex to FISH analysis. H.L. Gustafson, N. Theiss, H.J. Hnatyszyn Ventana Medical Systems, Tucson, AZ. Introduction: The need for next-generation sequencing (NGS) workflows is rapidly increasing as the sequencing technology matures and becomes more feasible as a diagnostic tool. Characterizing the tumor profile with as much information as possible is important to identify patient populations that may be poor responders to standard therapies, or would benefit from alternative therapeutic strategies. Driven by tissue context, sequencing joined with immuno-histochemical (IHC) tests for specific markers can provide comprehensive information to inform clinicians on potential treatment pathways. We have developed and evaluated an integrated workflow solution in our CAP/CLIA accredited laboratory that combines the use of IHC, digital imaging, automated micro-dissection, and targeted sequencing to capture important information to drive therapeutic opportunities. Methods: Our Integrated Companion Diagnostics (ICDx) workflow involves staining of a FFPE specimen using a validated IHC test for a specific biomarker with selected area(s) excised on subsequent serial sections by automated micro-dissection. The captured FFPE tissue then passes through our NGS workflow. To demonstrate, we excised tumor regions or used whole tissue resections from 20 cases (prostate, NSCLC, or breast) and DNA was sequenced utilizing commercial panels available for both Thermo Fisher's PGM and Illumina's MiSeq for comparison. Results: We found that samples acquired from automated micro-dissection are suitable for use in both downstream workflows for NGS library preparation and sequencing, however, not all samples provided adequate DNA yields for use with the selected Illumina targeted sequencing panel. This data provided comprehensive information about the tumor profile and suggest potential diagnostic IHC markers that should be screened for. Additionally, we found that the use of tissue dissection in regions of interest can allow for detection of mutations that would otherwise go undetected in greater than 75% of cases, several of which were clinically actionable. Conclusions: Ventana Medical System's Integrated CDx Workflow is designed to provide a comprehensive approach to personalized therapy, available in a CAP/CLIA accredited laboratory, and help provide pharma partners with information to support design of pivotal trials, including the selection of combination therapies. In non-small cell lung cancers (NSCLC), EGFR T790M mutations make up the most frequent cause of resistance to second-generation EGFR-tyrosine kinase inhibitors highlighting the importance of detecting these mutations early. The clinical performances of a number of different ddPCR assays have been recently reported for detection of EGFR T790M mutation in plasma cell-free DNA (cfDNA). However, there is limited literature available comparing the analytical characteristics of different ddPCR platforms and reagents. Here we compare the performance of two platforms and 4 unique reagents for detection of the T790M mutation. Methods: Three reagents sets (BioRad's commercial T790M assay, an IDT DNA custom reagent set and a reagent set designed by RainDance Technologies) were evaluated on the BioRad QX200 ddPCR system for analytical assay characteristics, using FFPE DNA and commercial cfDNA standards and controls. In addition, the RainDance Technologies reagent set was evaluated on the RainDrop Digital PCR system. Analytical sensitivity and specificity, assay precision and method/reagent concordance were assessed across platforms using the same DNA material. Reference material for these studies were generated from wild-type and mutant synthetic gBLOCKs TM , sheared genomic DNA from T790M positive cell lines, as well as commercially available cfDNA standards (Horizon Discovery). For accuracy and concordance, DNA was extracted from FFPE tissue samples either positive for EGFR T790M as measured by the Roche Cobas EGFR mutation test or presumed negative (melanoma BRAF V600E positive) samples. For specificity studies, cfDNA from donors free of malignancy were used. Results: All assays had acceptable linearity (R 2 >0.99, slope 0.9-1.1) from 30% to 0.3% fractional abundance at inputs of 40ng, 20ng, 10ng and 5 ng of sheared cell-line DNA. Analytical sensitivity experiments showed a limit of detection of 0.1% mutant in 20 ng of total DNA input. Accuracy studies using reference standards and controls indicated all assays fell within 20% of the expected result. All assays failed to detect T790M mutations in FFPE melanoma tissue samples as well as control plasma cfDNA (100% specificity) but correctly identified all T790M positive FFPE tumor samples with the fractional abundance CVs across all 4 assays between 1.3% and 16%. Conclusions: All assays and platforms performed with acceptable analytical characteristics. Therefore, results obtained on different platforms maybe communicable and the decision to implement a particular platform and reagent set should be primarily made based on cost, total analytical time and throughput. M. Poulin, A. Meyer, E.A. Mead, J. Xu, R. Drennan, L. Yan EpigenDx, Hopkinton, MA. Introduction: Approximately 15% to 25% of patients with lung adenocarcinoma have tumor associated KRAS mutations and approximately 30% to 50% of colorectal tumors are known to have a mutated KRAS gene. These mutations have most commonly been observed in codons 12 and 13 of the KRAS protein as well as in codons 61 and 146. There are many different assays and technologies that are used to detect these mutations all with various degrees of sensitivity, cost and turn-around time. We have compared four technologies, real-time PCR, pyrosequencing, nextgen sequencing and digital PCR. We examined assay sensitivity, cost and turnaround time to highlight the advantages and disadvantages of each of these detection technologies. Methods: Sensitivity and limit of detection tests were done by diluting known mutant DNA with wild-type DNA. We also compared the ability to detect mutations in 62 individual samples. Standard protocols for pyrosequencing and next-generation sequencing using the Ion-Torrent PGM platform developed in our laboratory, commercial assay utilizing the ARMS and Scorpion real-time technology and a taqman based digital PCR assay were all compared using the dilution series DNA as well as the 62 individual samples. Result: The pyrosequencing assays were able to detect mutations in samples that contained at least 10% KRAS DNA, at the minimal cost and a turnaround time of three days. Although the digital PCR and next-gen sequencing was able to detect mutations with at least 1% mutation, there were disadvantages of both cost and turnaround time in these assay platforms. The real-time ARMS/Scorpion assay had a rapid turnaround time, however it is only recommended for mutation dilutions of 20% and above. Conclusion: Each technology that was utilized to detect the various KRAS mutations has its advantages and disadvantages. We show that our validated pyrosequencing assays can rapidly detect KRAS mutations in tissue that contains at least 10% mutant DNA, with the versatility to examine all the mutations within codon 12, 13, 61 and 146.

back_matter.text: J. Ching 1 , K. Yang 2 , N. Ching 1 , L. Du 2 , S. Li 2 1 Coyote Bioscience, Campbell CA; 2 Coyote Bioscience, Beijing, China. Introduction: A key challenge of infectious disease detection by PCR or molecular methods is sample preparation or nucleic acid purification of clinical samples prior to PCR amplification to remove any inhibitory agents. Furthermore, quantitative or q-PCR is a difficult process that involves standards and controls for calibration. By combining a PCR reagent or master mix that requires no nucleic acid purification coupled to digital PCR, absolute quantitation of infectious organisms, simplifies molecular testing in the laboratory and point-of-care settings. Methods: A PCR reagent (One-Step PCR Reagent) was obtained from Coyote Bioscience (Beijing, China) and evaluated with Digital PCR and q-PCR for detection of virus in contrived clinical samples consisting of serum and HBV simulant (Coyote Bioscience, Beijing). Contrived clinical samples (10 IU/reaction) were run with and without nucleic acid purification. The purified nucleic acid was processed using Qiagen QIAamp DNA Mini Kit as a control. The purified nucleic acid and unpurified serum sample were placed into separate tubes containing One-Step PCR Reagent and analyzed with quantitative PCR and digital PCR. For both digital PCR and q-PCR a novel formulation involving Fluorinert FC-70 (Sigma Aldrich) and Tween 60 were used to form droplets for PCR amplification. The PCR master mix and target virus or nucleic acid were encased inside an aqueous droplet surrounded by an oil layer prior to PCR amplification. Results: The droplets formed for q-PCR and Digital PCR were stable at high temperature (100°C) and tolerated long cycling times (80 cycles) without deformation or merging of droplets. Direct detection of HBV in serum was achieved by both methods (q-PCR and Digital PCR). The control or purified nucleic acid was also detected by both methods. Conclusion: Combining the One-Step PCR Reagent and novel formulation (Fluorinert FC-70 and Tween 60) with PCR methods such as q-PCR and Digital PCR, simplified workflow for infectious disease testing. Introduction: Detection of cytogenetic and genomic abnormalities in MDS is used for diagnosis, classification, and monitoring. Compared to other cytogenetic methodologies, cytogenomic SNP microarray analysis (SNP-A) provides increased resolution for detection of copy number variants (CNVs) and can detect regions of loss-of -heterozygosity (LOH), which may enhance disease classification and prognostic stratification in MDS. In addition, recent studies have shown that as opposed to metaphase cytogenetics and interphase FISH, which are performed in situ, molecular analysis by SNP-A or NGS can be performed on peripheral blood specimens of patients with MDS with sensitivity comparable to bone marrow (BM). As DNA used in molecular testing of peripheral blood (PB) may be derived from cellfree DNA (cfDNA), we compared SNP-A detection sensitivity in whole blood (WB) versus plasma cfDNA to evaluate whether cfDNA may have clinical utility in MDS. Methods: A total of 12 paired samples were evaluated by SNP-A; all samples showed genomic abnormalities by karyotype, FISH and/or SNP-A on BM. Genomic DNA (gDNA) was extracted from WB (0.3 mL) with PureGene (Qiagen) and quantitated by Nanodrop (ThermoFisher). Plasma cfDNA was extracted from 6-9 mL WB by high-speed centrifugation followed by a modified CheMagic protocol (PerkinElmer). To measure cfDNA integrity/extraction efficiency, a pilot study was done on 16 MDS samples quantified by Qubit (ThermoFisher) and size measured by Caliper LabChip (PerkinElmer). SNP-A was performed using the CytoScan kit (Affymetrix) and analyzed with Chromosome Analysis Suite (ChAS; Affymetrix). All samples were collected with approval from the University of Utah Institutional Review Board. Results: SNP-A analysis of paired WB gDNA and plasma cfDNA samples showed 100% concordance in abnormality detection (n=12), consistent with the presence of tumor DNA in the cfDNA plasma fraction. SNP-A clonal burden (CB) ranged from 10% to 100% for WB (median=45%) and 20% to 100% for cfDNA (median= 80%) (t=0.03). Comparing detection sensitivities between these samples showed a higher level in cfDNA for 9/12 (75%) samples, suggesting enrichment. However, the data quality by SNP-A on cfDNA was poorer as compared to WB (median PB waviness QC= 0.1; median cfDNA waviness QC= 0.15). Conclusions: These results provide evidence that tumor DNA present in the plasma cfDNA fraction contributes to the detection sensitivity of genomic abnormalities from the peripheral blood of patients with MDS. The observation of increased clonal burden in the majority of cfDNA samples suggests that enrichment may have clinical utility for monitoring in MDS by molecular technologies. Future work will include efforts to improve the data quality from cfDNA by SNP-A analysis.
